It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) addressing social-related processing, meeting inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social perception (trustworthiness and fear appraisal of faces) that includes a healthy adult control group (n=17; ages 18–45). The study used whole-brain, univariate voxelwise analyses (mixed-effects group analyses via FSL/FEAT) and reports whole-brain task contrasts and cluster results (including coordinates referenced in Supplementary Tables) for task-evoked activity and task contrasts (fearfulness vs. trustworthiness and trustworthiness-specific networks), as well as group comparisons. The healthy control group is explicitly reported and results are described for task-related activation (including control ROI responses and whole-brain contrasts), meeting the requirement for whole-brain, group-level univariate task-evoked maps generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or out-of-range ages) are violated.

studies.title: But do you think I'm cool? Developmental differences in striatal recruitment during direct and reflected social self-evaluations.
studies.abstract: The current fMRI study investigates the neural foundations of evaluating oneself and others during early adolescence and young adulthood. Eighteen early adolescents (ages 11-14, M=12.6) and 19 young adults (ages 22-31, M=25.6) evaluated whether academic, physical, and social traits described themselves directly (direct self-evaluations), described their best friend directly (direct other-evaluations), described themselves from their best friend's perspective (reflected self-evaluations), or in general could change over time (control malleability-evaluations). Compared to control evaluations, both adolescents and adults recruited cortical midline structures during direct and reflected self-evaluations, as well as during direct other-evaluations, converging with previous research. However, unique to this study was a significant three-way interaction between age group, evaluative perspective, and domain within bilateral ventral striatum. Region of interest analyses demonstrated a significant evaluative perspective by domain interaction within the adolescent sample only. Adolescents recruited greatest bilateral ventral striatum during reflected social self-evaluations, which was positively correlated with age and pubertal development. These findings suggest that reflected social self-evaluations, made from the inferred perspective of a close peer, may be especially self-relevant, salient, or rewarding to adolescent self-processing--particularly during the progression through adolescence - and this feature persists into adulthood.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of social self/other evaluations (social-related processing). Includes a healthy young adult group (ages 22–31), which falls within the 17–65 inclusion range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an empirical fMRI study that includes a healthy adult group (N=19, ages 22–31) within the 17–65 range. The task is social-related (direct, reflected, and close-other self-evaluations across social, academic, and physical domains). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate analyses (2×4×3 whole-brain repeated-measures ANOVA; voxel-wise threshold p<0.005, cluster-extent k=64, AlphaSim FWE correction) and describes significant main effects and interactions; separate adult and adolescent comparisons are reported (with adult results described in main text and supplementary materials). Results are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked maps from a healthy adult sample performing a social task.

studies.title: Autism spectrum traits predict the neural response to eye gaze in typical individuals.
studies.abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) are neurodevelopmental disorders characterised by impaired social interaction and communication, restricted interests and repetitive behaviours. The severity of these characteristics are posited to lie on a continuum extending into the typical population, and typical adults' performance on behavioural tasks that are impaired in ASD is correlated with the extent to which they display autistic traits (as measured by Autism Spectrum Quotient, AQ). Individuals with ASD also show structural and functional differences in brain regions involved in social perception. Here we show that variation in AQ in typically developing individuals is associated with altered brain activity in the neural circuit for social attention perception while viewing others' eye gaze. In an fMRI experiment, participants viewed faces looking at variable or constant directions. In control conditions, only the eye region was presented or the heads were shown with eyes closed but oriented at variable or constant directions. The response to faces with variable vs. constant eye gaze direction was associated with AQ scores in a number of regions (posterior superior temporal sulcus, intraparietal sulcus, temporoparietal junction, amygdala, and MT/V5) of the brain network for social attention perception. No such effect was observed for heads with eyes closed or when only the eyes were presented. The results demonstrate a relationship between neurophysiology and autism spectrum traits in the typical (non-ASD) population and suggest that changes in the functioning of the neural circuit for social attention perception is associated with an extended autism spectrum in the typical population.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study investigating neural responses to eye gaze (social attention perception) in typically developing (healthy) adults; not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text to confirm age range and detailed methods.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social processing (eye-gaze perception) in a sample of healthy adults (N=18; ages 18–30). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain second-level analyses: specifically, SPM-t maps showing voxels whose activation (variable vs. constant gaze contrast) correlate with Autism Spectrum Quotient (AQ) across participants, thresholded at p<0.05 whole-brain FDR and reported with coordinates. These are univariate, within-group whole-brain task-evoked results (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only) and are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Although the simple main effect contrast lacked significant activations, the AQ regression constitutes an acceptable within-group whole-brain map generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Regional brain responses in nulliparous women to emotional infant stimuli.
studies.abstract: Infant cries and facial expressions influence social interactions and elicit caretaking behaviors from adults. Recent neuroimaging studies suggest that neural responses to infant stimuli involve brain regions that process rewards. However, these studies have yet to investigate individual differences in tendencies to engage or withdraw from motivationally relevant stimuli. To investigate this, we used event-related fMRI to scan 17 nulliparous women. Participants were presented with novel infant cries of two distress levels (low and high) and unknown infant faces of varying affect (happy, sad, and neutral) in a randomized, counter-balanced order. Brain activation was subsequently correlated with scores on the Behavioral Inhibition System/Behavioral Activation System scale. Infant cries activated bilateral superior and middle temporal gyri (STG and MTG) and precentral and postcentral gyri. Activation was greater in bilateral temporal cortices for low- relative to high-distress cries. Happy relative to neutral faces activated the ventral striatum, caudate, ventromedial prefrontal, and orbitofrontal cortices. Sad versus neutral faces activated the precuneus, cuneus, and posterior cingulate cortex, and behavioral activation drive correlated with occipital cortical activations in this contrast. Behavioral inhibition correlated with activation in the right STG for high- and low-distress cries relative to pink noise. Behavioral drive correlated inversely with putamen, caudate, and thalamic activations for the comparison of high-distress cries to pink noise. Reward-responsiveness correlated with activation in the left precentral gyrus during the perception of low-distress cries relative to pink noise. Our findings indicate that infant cry stimuli elicit activations in areas implicated in auditory processing and social cognition. Happy infant faces may be encoded as rewarding, whereas sad faces activate regions associated with empathic processing. Differences in motivational tendencies may modulate neural responses to infant cues.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Event-related fMRI measured responses to infant cries/faces (social stimuli involving affiliation/attachment and perception of others) in 17 healthy nulliparous adult women. Meets inclusion criteria (fMRI social task, healthy adult group) and is not a review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of nulliparous healthy adult women (ages 19–29) using task-based social stimuli (infant cries and faces) addressing social/affiliative and emotion perception processes. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate voxelwise contrasts (e.g., high- vs low-distress cries, happy vs neutral faces) with correction for multiple comparisons and displays results in figures/tables. Participants are healthy adults within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

studies.title: Limbic Interference During Social Action Planning in Schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Schizophrenia is characterized by social interaction deficits contributing to poor functional outcome. Hand gesture use is particularly impaired, linked to frontal lobe dysfunction and frontal grey matter deficits. The functional neural correlates of impaired gesturing are currently unclear. We therefore investigated aberrant brain activity during impaired gesturing in schizophrenia. We included 22 patients with schizophrenia and 25 healthy control participants matched for age, gender, and education level. We obtained functional magnetic resonance imaging data using an event-related paradigm to assess brain activation during gesture planning and execution. Group differences in whole brain effects were calculated using factorial designs. Gesture ratings were performed by a single rater, blind to diagnoses and clinical presentation. During gesture planning and execution both groups activated brain areas of the praxis network. However, patients had reduced dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) and increased inferior parietal lobe (IPL) activity. Performance accuracy was associated with IPL activity in patients. Furthermore, patients activated temporal poles, amygdala and hippocampus during gesture planning, which was associated with delusion severity. Finally, patients demonstrated increased dorsomedial prefrontal cortex activity during planning of novel gestures. We demonstrate less prefrontal, but more IPL and limbic activity during gesturing in schizophrenia. IPL activity was associated with performance accuracy, whereas limbic activity was linked to delusion severity. These findings may reflect impaired social action planning and a limbic interference with gestures in schizophrenia contributing to poor gesture performance and consequently poor social functioning in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study investigating gesture planning/execution (social communication) with both schizophrenia patients and a healthy control group matched for age and demographics. Task assesses social action/communication relevant to review. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports task-based fMRI of gesture planning/execution (a social-communication/social-action task) in healthy adult controls (n=25) alongside patients. The paper provides within-group, whole-brain, univariate task activation results for the healthy/control group (within-group results and whole-brain contrasts are described and thresholded), not only between-group contrasts or ROI/connectivity analyses. Healthy participants are adults and results for the healthy group are reported separately and generalizable. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain univariate healthy-group maps). No exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Oxytocin Facilitates Approach Behavior to Positive Social Stimuli via Decreasing Anterior Insula Activity.
studies.abstract: The neuropeptide oxytocin can extensively modulate human social behavior and affective processing, and its effects can be interpreted in terms of mediating approach-avoidance motivational processes. However, little is known about how oxytocin mediates approach-avoidance behavior and particularly the underlying neural mechanisms.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract does not specify methods or participant details, but title/aim indicate neural mechanisms of oxytocin on social stimuli—likely an fMRI study of social processing. Given insufficient methodological detail in the abstract to confirm fMRI and sample, include for full-text review to verify that a functional MRI task was used with healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task: fMRI during a social-related approach-avoidance task using social vs nonsocial emotional scenes (social processing). (2) Sample: healthy adult participants (male students, n=76 analyzed; mean age 21.35, within 17–65). (3) Whole-brain evidence: although many primary ROI/SVC results are reported, the paper explicitly states exploratory whole-brain analyses were conducted and reported (P<.05 corrected) and presents group-level task-evoked contrasts derived from the healthy sample (maps/tables reported in main text and/or supplementary materials). Results are univariate, group-level, and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical fMRI work (task-based) and does not fall under exclusion categories (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adult group reported separately). Hence it should be included.

studies.title: Concrete versus abstract forms of social concept: an fMRI comparison of knowledge about people versus social terms.
studies.abstract: The anterior temporal lobes (ATLs) play a key role in conceptual knowledge representation. The hub-and-spoke theory suggests that the contribution of the ATLs to semantic representation is (a) transmodal, i.e. integrating information from multiple sensorimotor and verbal modalities, and (b) pan-categorical, representing concepts from all categories. Another literature, however, suggests that this region's responses are modality- and category-selective; prominent examples include category selectivity for socially relevant concepts and face recognition. The predictions of each approach have never been directly compared. We used data from three studies to compare category-selective responses within the ATLs. Study 1 compared ATL responses to famous people versus another conceptual category (landmarks) from visual versus auditory inputs. Study 2 compared ATL responses to famous people from pictorial and written word inputs. Study 3 compared ATL responses to a different kind of socially relevant stimuli, namely abstract non-person-related words, in order to ascertain whether ATL subregions are engaged for social concepts more generally or only for person-related knowledge. Across all three studies a dominant bilateral ventral ATL cluster responded to
studies.journal: Philosophical transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological sciences
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Primary data fMRI study examining neural responses to famous people and abstract social words (social concepts), across modalities. Tasks assess social-related processing (knowledge about others/social concepts). Likely conducted in healthy adult participants and not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (combined n=59 across three studies, ages consistent with adult range), using social-related paradigms (person knowledge: famous faces/names; socially relevant concept words). The manuscript presents group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., social > non-social semantics) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster correction, peak coordinates, figures, and detailed whole-brain results described in the text. Healthy/control group results are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. The study is empirical and not ROI-only (ROIs are supplementary to whole-brain analyses). No exclusion criteria are met, so the study satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Resting-state fMRI study of children (age 7–12) including ASD and typically developing controls; no task-based social processing in healthy adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria (age range and task-based social fMRI).

Abstract describes an fMRI experiment where human perceivers performed a social emotion-inference task (learning about others’ emotions), directly addressing social cognition. It is empirical original research (not a review). Participant health/age not specified in the abstract; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Participants are early adolescents (aged 10.5–13.4), outside the included adult age range (17–65). Additionally, the study used resting-state fMRI and MR spectroscopy rather than a task-based fMRI social processing paradigm, so it does not meet the task-based fMRI criterion.

Abstract suggests an empirical neuroimaging study of social inference in PTSD but does not explicitly state that an fMRI task was used or that healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included. Not a review/meta-analysis. Insufficient detail in abstract to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

This is a review article discussing neuroimaging and behavioral studies in high-functioning autism rather than an original fMRI study with healthy adult participants; thus it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Abstract describes a narrative/review on development of the social brain in adolescence, summarizing structural MRI and fMRI findings and speculating about implications. It is not an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults (17–65) and meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study where participants made self-descriptiveness judgments (perception/understanding of self), which is social-related processing; participants appear to be healthy adults (no clinical groups reported). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

The article is a meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI studies (neuroimaging meta-analysis), not a primary fMRI experiment with human participants; exclusion criterion disallows reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI conducted in healthy human participants (15 healthy males) examining oxytocin effects on amygdala during fear-inducing stimuli; topic aligns with social cognition. Abstract lacks detail on whether the stimuli are explicitly social (e.g., faces) and does not state participant ages, so full-text review warranted to confirm social-task relevance and age range.

Task involved social interaction (provocation/retaliation) during fMRI in healthy adult participants (healthy males), addressing social-emotional processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Dual (hyperscanning) functional MRI conducted while participants engaged in interactive social exchange (cooperation vs competition). Study investigates social cognition processes in (presumably) healthy adult pairs and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports two fMRI experiments testing theory-of-mind/social interaction processing (intentions in social contexts). This matches the review objective (social-related fMRI tasks). Participant health/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study in human participants (N=17) using social stimuli (love and power movie clips) probing affiliation and power motivations—social processing relevant to review. Participants appear to be healthy adults; study is empirical (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

This publication is a large-scale meta-analysis of ~10,000 fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. The review/meta-analysis exclusion criterion is met, so the study should be excluded.

fMRI was conducted during social tasks (face-to-face conversation vs repetition) and the study includes a group of typically developing (healthy) control adults age-matched to autistic participants. Thus it fits the review’s focus on social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Resting-state fMRI study in individuals with autism spectrum conditions (clinical sample), not a task-based social processing fMRI in healthy adults. No healthy adult group or social task described, so does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating communicative actions (speech acts) and neural correlates of social communication—directly relevant to social-related processing. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages; include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics.

Primary research using fMRI to examine social cognitive processing (social working memory) in humans; not a review. Abstract implies healthy adult participants (individual differences reported) and addresses perception/understanding of others, meeting inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI studies.

Abstract reports fMRI of reward processing and maternal affiliation (a social/affiliation construct) but participants are described as 'adolescents' with no ages given. Inclusion requires healthy participants aged 17–65; age/adult status is unclear. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and eligibility.

fMRI task contrasted social vs non-social stimuli and included a matched healthy control group (14 controls). Study involves social perception processing in humans and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for healthy adult participants.

fMRI was conducted while human participants performed social-cognitive tasks (passive observation and emotion attribution/judgment), targeting perception/understanding of others. Participants appear to be healthy adults; study is empirical (not a review). Satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social cognition (face judgments of trustworthiness/age). Includes a nonclinical control group (healthy participants). Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion not explicitly confirmed), so include for full-text verification.

fMRI study using emotional face (social) go/no-go tasks and includes a neurotypical control group (healthy participants). Not a review. Abstract doesn’t state participant ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm age range.

This is a narrative review of early brain development and infant fMRI methods rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults (ages 17–65). It is a review article (not primary data) and focuses on infants, so does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during a social-related face-encoding task and includes an age- and gender-matched healthy control group. The abstract does not report participants’ ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.

The paper is explicitly an fMRI Activation Likelihood Estimation (ALE) meta-analysis. The review's exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews or meta-analyses should be excluded, so this study is excluded based on the abstract alone.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsfMRI) acquired before and after rTMS, with no social-related task or social processing during scanning. Thus it does not meet the inclusion criterion of task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study in human participants involving social interaction (eye gaze, socially relevant facial expressions) and social-communication/self-relevance processes. Abstract implies healthy human participants and directly addresses the review objective. No exclusion criteria met; age not specified but sufficient to include for full-text review.

fMRI was conducted during an empathy task (social processing) and the study included a healthy control group alongside schizophrenia patients. Abstract does not report participant ages explicitly, so full text should confirm they fall within 17–65, but inclusion criteria for having at least one healthy adult group are met based on abstract.

fMRI study of social-cognitive processing with a healthy control group, but participants are aged 10–18. Abstract does not confirm presence of healthy adults within the required 17–65 range. Insufficient information to determine adult-only inclusion, so include for full-text review.

Abstract compares neural signatures of self- vs other-touch in adults including neurotypical controls, addressing social-related processing (self/other perception) and includes healthy adult group. The abstract does not specify the imaging modality (fMRI); therefore include for full-text review to confirm that a task-based fMRI was used.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using a social cognition task (theory of mind/empathy), directly addressing social-related processing. It reports 70 subjects but does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65). Because key inclusion details (healthy adult group and age range) are not clearly stated in the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports only schizophrenia patients (with and without SUD; n=12 and n=11) and does not include any healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants (age 17–65). Therefore excluded.

fMRI study directly probes social interaction and joint attention using live face-to-face tasks that engage social cognition and reward systems. Participants are described as human (healthy) interactants with no clinical groups mentioned. Meets the review objective (social processing in healthy adults). Abstract does not state ages, but inclusion is warranted; full text can confirm exact age range if needed.

fMRI study with social-related task (adolescents viewing parent videos tapping social cognition/mentalizing). Participants reported as healthy adolescents with mean age 17, which meets the 17–65 age criterion. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text data extraction.

Abstract indicates this is a review article summarizing neuroimaging studies of social cognition in MDD. Exclusion criteria remove systematic reviews/meta-analyses; no original fMRI data in healthy adults are reported in the abstract.

fMRI study investigating empathy/social cognition while participants viewed emotional vs neutral social scenes—directly addresses social processing. Not a review. Abstract implies healthy adult participants performing a social-related task; full text needed to confirm participant ages/health, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining neural processing of social hierarchy (status) during an interactive social task in humans. It addresses social perception/understanding and is not a review. Participant health/age not explicitly stated in abstract, but no indication of clinical sample; per criteria, include for full-text if unsure. Meets inclusion for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Resting-state fMRI study with no task-based social processing; inclusion requires a social-related task during fMRI. Although controls are included, the absence of task-based social paradigm excludes this study.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task-based social processing during scan). Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social-related tasks in healthy adults; this study examines resting connectivity across the lifespan and likely includes ages outside 17–65.

This is a resting-state fMRI study comparing schizophrenia patients and healthy controls; no social-related task or social processing paradigm is reported. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social processing, so exclude based on the abstract.

fMRI was conducted during processing of emotional faces, which is a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). The study is original research (not a review). The abstract does not explicitly report participant health status or ages, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study of social cognition (affective Theory of Mind, emotion recognition) performed during task-based scanning and includes a matched healthy control group. Fits the meta-analysis objective. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion not explicitly confirmed), so include for full-text review to verify age range and other details.

Study used resting-state fMRI in adolescents (ages 14–26) rather than a task-based social processing fMRI. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults (17–65). Although authors reference overlap with social-cognition maps, no social task was performed and the sample includes participants below the adult age range.

Abstract reports functional MRI activity (superior temporal sulcus) during two social-cognitive tasks measuring social processing, and links results to behavioral and self-report measures. Participants appear to be human adults and no exclusion criteria (e.g., review article) apply. Therefore it meets the fMRI social-processing in healthy adults inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a baby-cry attachment-related task investigating maternal self/other processing (social/affiliation construct). Includes a healthy adult control group (n=15). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of socio-cognitive processing using social/traffic videos in adult driver groups (safe vs dangerous). Tasks probe perception/understanding of others; participants appear to be healthy adults. Meets inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task-based social processing) and participants were children (not healthy adults aged 17–65). Although it includes healthy controls, neither the required adult age range nor a social-task fMRI are met.

fMRI social-judgment task directly assesses social reward/processing (acceptance/rejection). Study includes a matched healthy control group alongside anorexia patients, satisfying requirement for at least one healthy participant group. Age range not specified in abstract, but population appears adult; if unclear, full-text can confirm ages. Relevant to social processing in healthy adults—include for full-text review.

Resting-state fMRI study with intranasal oxytocin; participants did not perform a social-related task during scanning. Does not meet inclusion criterion requiring task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social task) and participants were adolescents (means ~14.5 years, range 10.0–18.0) with no healthy adult group aged 17–65, so it fails the task and age inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 30 healthy adult participants performing an empathy-for-pain task modulated by ingroup/outgroup—directly assesses social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of eye contact, a social processing task, and identifies neural networks underlying reciprocal social interaction. It is not a review. The abstract does not specify participant age or explicit statement of healthy adult sample; information is insufficient to determine eligibility, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study using a social task (modified Cyberball combining exclusion and performance evaluation) examining neural correlates of social processing. Abstract does not state participant health status or ages (17–65), so insufficient to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study with 20 human participants performing a social decision-making task (modified prisoner's dilemma) probing Theory of Mind/perception of others. Involves healthy adult participants and addresses social processing. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI while participants passively viewed a cinematic social-affective scene (social cognition/ToM/affiliation). It includes a healthy control group alongside schizophrenia patients, meeting the review’s task and population criteria. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text review.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan during a social-related task; although healthy controls are present, the absence of a task means it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract does not specify whether an fMRI task of social processing was performed or whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included. The study focuses on network centrality in bvFTD and social-executive performance, so methods are unclear; include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract reports behavioral and fMRI findings from 22 typically developing adults performing a social attribution/mentalizing task (DISC). This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults and meets the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cooperation (Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult participants; addresses social processing (perception/understanding of others, affiliation). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Study reports simultaneous EEG and fMRI during a group categorization task manipulating in-group/out-group emotional face processing—clearly a social-related task with fMRI data. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of prosocial learning and empathy—clearly a social processing task relevant to perception/understanding of others. Abstract reports human participants but does not state ages or explicit health status; per screening rules, if insufficient info on participant health/age, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Functional MRI was used to study neural mechanisms of social tie formation during a public good game—clearly a social-processing task. Abstract does not state participant age/health, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and eligibility.

Task-based fMRI study investigating reappraisal of angry faces (social/emotional face processing) with resting-state connectivity; involves human participants and reports neural correlates of social emotion regulation in (presumably) healthy adult sample. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults; abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Functional MRI study of social processing (participants imagined triadic social interactions), not a review. Neural activations for mentalizing and mirror systems reported. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text screening to confirm healthy adult sample and demographics.

fMRI study of social reward (feedback about being liked) in late adolescents (ages 18–21), which falls within the 17–65 range; participants appear to be a nonclinical sample varying in social anhedonia. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI performed on 36 healthy adult participants during vocal emotional processing (social communication/perception task). Fits inclusion: task-based fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review.

fMRI study of social gaze processing (social communication/perception) in humans. Abstract implies healthy adult participants though ages aren’t specified; meets review objective. Include for full-text to confirm participant age/health details.

Resting-state fMRI study comparing MDD patients and healthy controls; no task-based social processing paradigm reported. Inclusion requires task fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults, so this study does not meet the primary criterion.

The article is a methodological tutorial/review of intersubject correlation analysis and does not report original fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social-related tasks. It is a review/methods paper, meeting the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract suggests study of face-processing (a social cognition domain) and likely uses fMRI, but it does not specify whether healthy adult controls (age 17–65) were included or whether tasks were performed during fMRI. Insufficient detail to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review to confirm methods and participant groups.

Abstract reports fMRI in male adult participants performing reflection on one’s own and a friend’s social attributes (self/other social cognition tasks). Participants appear to be healthy adults within the target age range. Study is original research (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI processing in healthy adults.

Study includes only patients with schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder (N=47) and does not report any healthy control group. Meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65. Although it uses fMRI and a social (ToM) task, it fails the healthy-participant inclusion criterion.

fMRI study with n=21 healthy adult participants performing live bidirectional social interactions (human-human vs human-robot). Investigates neural markers of mentalizing and social motivation—directly addresses social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text data extraction.

Abstract does not specify whether fMRI was conducted during a social-related task or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Although focused on schizophrenia, it may include healthy controls for comparison. Insufficient information in abstract to confirm inclusion/exclusion; include for full-text review.

Human fMRI study using a task where participants evaluated political beliefs — a form of social cognition (perception/understanding of others/self). Reports neural correlates of social decision-making and self-other processing in healthy adults. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports behavioral and neural-level assessment of empathy and mentalizing in a large healthy sample (N=178) and uses dynamic causal modeling, indicating functional neuroimaging during social-cognitive tasks. No indication it's a review/meta-analysis and participants appear to be healthy adults. Although fMRI is not explicitly stated, the neural DCM approach and journal context strongly imply fMRI, so include for full-text review.

Participants are healthy older adults (mean age 79), outside the review’s eligible age range (17–65). The abstract reports only older adult participants and no qualifying younger adult group, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract focuses on neural connectivity in ASD but does not state whether fMRI was acquired during a social-related task or whether healthy adult participants (age 17–65) were included; could be resting-state or clinical-only. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study where participants encoded facts about unfamiliar people versus non-social stimuli; reports person-selective responses and connectivity with the social cognition network. Involves healthy adult participants and is primary research (not a review). Meets criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is a review article (narrative review) rather than an original fMRI study. The abstract does not report fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social tasks; it summarizes literature and presents a heuristic model. Per exclusion criteria (systematic reviews/meta-analyses), exclude.

fMRI was performed in healthy adult participants (observing and imitating bimanual actions) examining neural correlates of spontaneous imitation, a social-related process relevant to social interaction/communication. The task fits the review’s social processing scope and abstract indicates primary data collection in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Pilot study involves pediatric stroke patients and examines resting-state connectivity correlated with ToM performance rather than an fMRI task in healthy adults. Does not include healthy participants aged 17–65 or task-based social-processing fMRI, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy participants probing social interaction/theory-of-mind during human-human competition (social processing). Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract — include for full-text verification of participant ages and other details.

fMRI study where participants judged attractiveness of other people (and compared beauty), which is a social perception/understanding of others task in healthy adults. Abstract indicates task and neuroimaging; meets inclusion for social-related fMRI in adults. Full text can confirm age range and participant health.

fMRI study performing social-cognition tasks (face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM) and includes a healthy matched control group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages, so full text should confirm they fall within 17–65, but criteria otherwise met.

Study used fMRI BOLD to measure neural responses to perception of animacy from motion—a social-perception/‘perception of others’ task—in healthy human participants. Abstract lacks detailed age range but meets inclusion of fMRI social-related processing; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health.

fMRI study examining learning about others’ preferences—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Human participants with task-based fMRI; not a review. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details, so per guidelines include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
Participants were dogs (canine study), not human adults. Meta-analysis requires fMRI in healthy human participants aged 17–65; this animal study does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract mentions neural responses to emotional/social stimuli in schizophrenia and depression but does not specify imaging modality or participant ages. Likely includes healthy controls, but information is insufficient to confirm fMRI and age range—include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract describes ERP methods and a theoretical/review-style discussion of emotion development and neural plasticity. It does not report an fMRI task-based study or social-related task in healthy adults, and reads like a review. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using Cyberball and a modified Dictator Game probing punishment and forgiveness—clearly a social-related task addressing perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit healthy status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports fMRI experiments on biological motion perception—a social-perception task (perception/understanding of others)—and includes both schizophrenia and healthy individuals. Thus it meets fMRI + social task + healthy adult group criteria; abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Study used fMRI during a Cyberball social exclusion task (a social processing/affiliation paradigm). No clinical groups are mentioned and participants appear to be healthy adults. Meets the review objective and inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm age range and participant health status.

fMRI study using a social attribution/ToM task (moving shapes) and includes a healthy control group of women. Although ages are not explicitly stated, participants are described as women (likely adults); meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and extract data.

Event-related fMRI with human participants performing an interpersonal resource-conflict task addressing social processing (appraisal/resolution of interpersonal conflicts and sharing). No indication this is a review or involves clinical samples; meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social task in healthy adults. Include for full-text review.
Participants were infants (3–7 months). Inclusion criteria require at least one group of healthy adult participants aged 17–65. Therefore the study does not meet the age-eligibility criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment assessing neural responses to social exclusion (a social-related task) in 21 healthy adult volunteers. The study directly addresses social processing using fMRI in healthy adults and is not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy participants performing a task manipulating social vs non-social passages; examines neural substrates (dmPFC) of social cognition and links activity to social-cognition performance. Fits review objective and inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was used while participants performed a social interaction discrimination task (perception/understanding of others). The study includes a healthy adult group aged 20–41, within the 17–65 inclusion range, and is not a review. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=38) performing a social cognition task (mental state judgments) using naturalistic social stimuli. Fits the review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

Study uses event-related fMRI with social (positive social) stimuli, matching the review topic, but the abstract does not clearly state inclusion of a healthy adult control group (ages 17–65). Because information is insufficient to determine whether healthy participants are included, include for full-text review.

fMRI study investigating recall of relationship episodes (self and others), which assesses social cognitive processes (self/other understanding). Sample includes 35 healthy individuals. Abstract lacks ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

The study sample comprises "youth" (adolescents) with ASD and age-matched typically-developing controls, not healthy adults aged 17–65. The abstract indicates no adult participants, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion of healthy adult participants.

fMRI study examines self-, mother-, and abstract-other social processing (self-reference and theory-of-mind tasks), clearly social-related. Not a review. Abstract implies healthy adult participants; if uncertain, include for full-text review to confirm ages/health.

fMRI study examining emotional inference from vocalizations and music—addresses social cognition/social communication. Abstract reports task during fMRI and implies healthy adult participants, but does not specify ages or health status; therefore include for full-text review to confirm participant details.

fMRI was conducted during a social cognition task (HCP social paradigm) and the study includes a matched healthy control group (25 controls). Not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy adults investigating perception and understanding of social interactions (dyadic interactions, competition vs. cooperation) during task-based scanning. Fits inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy participants aged within range). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract discusses fMRI approaches and describes an attempted simultaneous fMRI measurement of joint attention and neural substrates of prosocial behavior, but it is unclear whether this reports original fMRI data in healthy adults (ages 17–65) or is a review. Insufficient detail to determine inclusion based on abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment (17 participants) using mentalising/theory-of-mind story tasks (social cognition) that recruited canonical social brain regions. It involves human participants performing a social-related task and is not a review. Age range not specified but participants are healthy adults; therefore it meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants observed and rated social (guest-host) interactions—this is a social-related task. At least one group of healthy adult participants (N=15) was tested. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.
Study uses fMRI during a simple motor task (cerebellar motor activation) in autism and controls; it does not investigate social-related processing, so it does not meet the review objective.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=64) performing a social cognition task (inferring others’ preferences vs. self), examining self–other processing in MPFC. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets the social-related task criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social cognition (attentional and attributional biases). It does not specify whether healthy adult participants were included. Because the task is social-related but participant composition is unclear, include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults.

fMRI experiments on voice recognition (social communication/perception) with matched healthy control group (adults, likely within 17–65). Not a review. Abstract indicates task-based fMRI in relevant social domain, so include for full-text review.

This is a quantitative review/meta-analysis of fMRI studies (activation likelihood estimation), not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

Study used fMRI while participants performed a third-party punishment task (social decision-making/perception of others). Participants described as lay people (healthy adults). Task examines social-related processing (moral responsibility, attribution). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was used to assess perception of point-light biological (body) motion—a social perception task (Perception/Understanding of Others). The study includes a group of healthy matched controls (adult sample) and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in children and adolescents with ASD (and age-matched child controls); it is not a task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults (17–65). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.
Participants are described as children/adolescents (ASD and typically developing); no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported. Therefore the study does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.
Participants are children (mean age 10.2 years); study does not include healthy adult participants within the required 17–65 age range for the review, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social-related processing (sadness introspection — perception/understanding of self). Participants are adolescents aged 16–17; abstract does not clearly confirm participants meet the review’s adult age criterion (17–65). Include for full-text review to verify age eligibility and confirm healthy adult group.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Although healthy controls were included, no social-related task was performed, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion of fMRI during a social task.

The paper is an ALE meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study. The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews/meta-analyses; abstract does not report primary data on healthy participants performing social tasks. Therefore exclude based on study type.

The study uses resting-state fMRI (RsFc) rather than a task-based fMRI of social-related processing. Inclusion requires participants to perform a social-related task during scanning; although healthy controls are included, no task is reported. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adults (mean age 24) performing a social-related task (social regulation via friend/stranger handholding during threat), addressing affiliation/attachment neural processing. Not a review; meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Participants are children and adolescents (not healthy adults aged 17–65). Additionally fMRI examined auditory processing and connectivity rather than a social-related task. Therefore it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of mentalizing (Prisoner’s Dilemma) probing attachment/affiliation; sample of 164 healthy adults; task examines perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was conducted while participants viewed and recognized dynamic facial expressions, a social-perception/understanding task. The study reports behavioral correlations and does not appear to be a review. Although ages aren’t specified in the abstract, the participant sample is presented as typical human participants; include for full-text verification of age/health criteria.

Primary research fMRI study examining social cognition (positivity motivation toward close vs. non-close others) in human participants; involves social-related tasks (perception/understanding of others). Appears to use healthy adult participants and is not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Human fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=24) performing an interactive social task involving self- and other-initiated joint attention and social-cognitive/self-processing measures. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study in humans using dynamic head turns to probe social attention (perception/understanding of others), which fits review’s social-processing objective. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state ages; insufficient detail for exclusion, so include for full-text review to confirm participant characteristics and ages.

fMRI was conducted while participants viewed emotionally charged movies and the study explicitly examines interpersonal understanding and social interaction (synchronization of brain activity across individuals). It involves healthy adult participants (age not specified in abstract). Not a review. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and task details.

fMRI was conducted during a social-related visual perspective-taking task and the study included a matched healthy adult control group (20 healthy volunteers). Meets inclusion criteria for task type and presence of healthy participants; not a review.

Healthy adult participants (153 men, 151 women) underwent fMRI while playing the iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma with human partners — a social interaction task probing cooperation/unreciprocated cooperation. This directly addresses social processing in healthy adults and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of face emotion discrimination (a social cognition task) in a community sample comparing high vs low social anhedonia. Involves healthy adult participants and directly examines social-related processing with functional imaging. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study examining self- vs other-serving (social) decisions—fits review objective. However, abstract reports a single case and does not state participant age or health status, so inclusion criteria re: healthy adults (17–65) cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to clarify.

fMRI study measuring neural activity while healthy adult friends performed a social-related task (social sharing/affiliation). Fits the review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Participants are described as adolescents (adolescent boys) rather than adults. The healthy control group is not within the required age range (17–65). Abstract gives no ages; cannot assume adult status, so study does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of social-related processing (guilt, social cognition regions) in humans. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65), so inclusion should be confirmed via full-text. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract reports decoding performance on social cognition tasks using HCP fMRI data but does not explicitly state participant age range or health status. Mentions social-related task but provides insufficient participant/task detail—include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65) and task specifics.

Study reports fMRI during tasks probing perception/understanding of self and others (social cognition). It includes a healthy control group alongside BPD patients (adult sample). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI social cognition task in schizophrenia patients but does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group and the abstract provides insufficient information, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Task-fMRI examined action-intention judgment (a social cognition task) and included a typically developing (healthy) participant group alongside ASD. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm age and other eligibility.

Participants are school-age children (N=32, ages 9–13), not within the required adult age range (17–65). Although the study uses fMRI and examines social cognition (ToM), it fails the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of action observation (watching others perform a task), addressing perception/understanding of others—a relevant social-processing construct. Conducted in human subjects with no indication of clinical populations in the abstract. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study in healthy adults using narrative listening tasks that probe mentalizing (understanding others' beliefs/intentions) and sensorimotor simulation. Directly addresses social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study of implicit facial emotion recognition—clearly a social-processing task. Participants are described as subjects with high genetic load for schizophrenia (GHR), likely unaffected relatives; abstract does not clearly state absence/presence of diagnosed disorder or control group, but inclusion criteria allow studies with at least one healthy group. Insufficient detail on participant health/ages in abstract, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining impression formation (perception/understanding of others), clearly a social-related task in humans. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract implies healthy adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social cognition (social judgments) which fits the review objective. The abstract does not explicitly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included; information is insufficient to determine exclusion. Per screening rules, include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult participants.

Primary fMRI study examining empathy (Perception and Understanding of Others), a social-related task, in healthy adult participants; not a review or meta-analysis. Fits the meta-analysis objective and inclusion criteria.

Real-time fMRI was conducted while volunteers played the ultimatum game, a social decision-making interaction involving perception/understanding of others. Participants are described as volunteers (healthy). This is an original empirical study, not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Resting-state fMRI study without an active social-related task during scanning. Although healthy controls are included, the inclusion criterion requires task-based social processing fMRI; abstract indicates only resting-state functional connectivity.

fMRI study investigating neural responses to others' physical and emotional pain (Theory of Mind and shared pain networks), which is clearly social processing. Uses human participant groups (replicated in two groups); not a review. Abstract does not report atypical populations or ages, so include for full-text to confirm participant health/age.

fMRI was used during a face perception/recognition task (social processing). The study includes healthy control subjects compared to a clinical case, meeting requirement for at least one healthy adult group. Age range not specified in abstract but participants are described as adult controls; full text can confirm ages if needed.

Participants are children (ASD and typically developing), not adults. The review requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65; this study includes no adult healthy group. Although it uses fMRI on social stimuli, the age criterion is not met.

fMRI study examining face processing (social perception) using a faces vs objects task; sample spans ages 6 through adulthood, thus includes healthy adults. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adult participants.

fMRI study explicitly investigates effects of social gaze on action control using a social vs nonsocial stimulus-response task, addressing social-related processing. Abstract does not report participant age/health explicitly; likely healthy adults but insufficient detail—include for full-text verification of sample characteristics.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (omnivores, vegetarians, vegans) performing social-related tasks (empathy/affective appraisal toward humans and animals). This fits the review’s social processing constructs and inclusion criteria; not a review article.

fMRI study examining processing of emotional facial expressions (social communication/perception) in humans and monkeys. Abstract indicates human participants and a social-related task, but does not report participant ages or explicit health status. Include for full-text review to confirm that human participants are healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI was used to measure brain responses to dynamic emotional facial expressions (social/emotion recognition task). Study includes matched healthy young adult control group (participants with familial risk plus controls), ages consistent with 17–65. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.
This is a resting-state fMRI study examining connectivity biomarkers; no task-based social processing was performed. Does not meet inclusion requirement of fMRI during a social-related task.

fMRI study investigating neural processing of dyadic social interactions (social perception/understanding) in human participants; not a review/meta-analysis. Participant health/ages not specified in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of self-evaluation, a social-related construct (Perception/Understanding of Self), with a matched healthy control group. Task performed during fMRI and includes adult participants; no exclusion criteria apply. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study investigating neural representations of self (general and contextual self), which falls under Perception and Understanding of Self; appears to involve healthy adult participants across cultures; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study scanning healthy adults while they viewed others in pain—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Meets inclusion criteria (functional MRI, social-related task, healthy participants). Not a review/meta-analysis and no exclusion criteria met.

Study used fMRI during a facial emotional processing task (social cognition). It includes a healthy adult control group matched for age and IQ (adults likely within 17–65) and is not a review. Abstract gives sufficient info to include.

Whole-brain fMRI was collected while participants viewed faces in real-world social networks, probing social cognition and valuation (perception/understanding of others). Participants are group members (presumably healthy adults within target age range). Study is empirical, not a review. Fits inclusion criteria.

Task-based fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind and empathy) in 13 healthy right-handed volunteers. Meets inclusion: social-related task and healthy participant group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state exact ages, but participants are described as volunteers (likely adults); include for full-text review to confirm age range if needed.

Abstract reports fMRI in 16 healthy volunteers performing a social interaction task (matching-pennies) involving human and non-human agents, addressing perception/understanding of others. This meets inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI in healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis and no exclusion criteria met.

The study used resting-state fMRI following intranasal oxytocin rather than an active social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social processing; resting-state connectivity does not meet this criterion, so exclude.

fMRI study directly examines social cognition (empathy, Theory of Mind, self–other differentiation), meeting the social-related task criterion. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study where participants viewed point-light displays of human locomotion—this is social-related (perception/understanding of others/biological motion). Uses healthy participants (implied) and meets inclusion of a social task. Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Task-based fMRI study examining processing of human voices (social communication/perception of others) using healthy human participants; not a review. The study assesses social-relevant auditory processing with BOLD responses, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI was conducted during social cognition tasks (theory of mind) and the study includes an age-, gender-, and education-matched healthy control group. It is an original fMRI study (not a review) and addresses social-related processing in adults, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult subjects (normal subjects) performing a social-related task (watching movie clips of everyday social interactions). Fits the review objective of social processing in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI was used during a communicative/retrieval task contrasting collaboratively- vs individually-learned labels, engaging mentalizing/theory-of-mind regions. Participants were healthy adults. Study is empirical, not a review.

The study investigates negative emotion processing and fronto-limbic connectivity; the abstract does not indicate a social-related task or social stimuli (e.g., perception of others, social communication, affiliation). Although likely involves healthy adults, it does not meet the review’s requirement of an explicit social-processing fMRI task.

Abstract indicates this is a review article on genetics and neuroimaging of autism rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adult participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Healthy adult participants underwent fMRI while performing a social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma). Study directly examines social processing and includes healthy subjects; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-task studies in healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

fMRI study measuring false-belief reasoning (theory-of-mind), a social-cognitive task (perception/understanding of others); includes large healthy adult comparison groups (480 adults). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.
Participants were non-human (dogs). The review requires fMRI studies with human participants aged 17–65; this canine fMRI study does not meet the population inclusion criterion.

Study II reports functional MRI during a social interaction/gaze paradigm relevant to social reward processing and includes a healthy control group. This matches the review objective (social-related fMRI in adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and task details.

This article is a meta-analysis across 12 fMRI studies examining the default-mode network and its relationship to social cognition. It is a secondary synthesis (meta-analysis), which meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study examining dynamic processing of facial expressions and social interaction cues (social-related task). Includes a group of participants without schizotypal traits (healthy controls). Although ages are not reported in the abstract, the study clearly meets the fMRI and healthy-group criteria for inclusion; full text can confirm ages if needed.

fMRI study with healthy late-adolescent participants (ages 18–22.8) performing a social-related task (observing risk-taking vs safe actions) probing social cognition and emotional processing. Participants fall within the 17–65 range and the study is original research, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.
Resting-state fMRI study in multiple sclerosis patients; no task-based social processing paradigm and no healthy adult control group reported in abstract. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Title and abstract indicate an fMRI study of facial emotion perception, a social processing task. The sample includes schizophrenia patients and nonpsychotic relatives (likely healthy adults). Abstract lacks explicit confirmation of a healthy control group and participant ages; include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy participants aged 17–65 and task details.

Event-related fMRI study of irony comprehension (a social-communication/social-cognition task) that included a healthy control group. Although one group comprised schizophrenia patients, healthy female controls were scanned (adult participants implied). Study directly addresses social-related processing in healthy adults.

Task-based fMRI using a social perception experiment is reported and the study includes a group of healthy adult control participants (n=21). Fits review focus on social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis.

Primary research using fMRI in healthy adult participants investigating social-cognitive processing (mirror neuron and mentalizing systems) during social-related tasks (action understanding/inferring mental states). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (all-female sample) performing a social perception task (viewing social vs random animations; social attention contrasts). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review. Sufficient information in abstract to include for full-text review.

Functional MRI was conducted during a social joint-action task (leading, following, mutual) involving physical interpersonal interaction; analyses report social-cognition, mentalizing, and social-reward processes. Participants are trained couple dancers (presumably healthy adults). This meets the criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Study uses fMRI while participants perform legal decision-making tasks probing social cognition (understanding others, emotion effects on reasoning). Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

Empirical fMRI study with 34 healthy adult participants viewing a naturalistic movie; investigates social processing (DMPFC responses to social interactions) during task-related scanning. Not a review or meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a functional brain imaging study of emotional sentence attribution (a social processing task). However, it does not explicitly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm the presence of healthy participants — include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

The study used functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS), not functional MRI. Although it investigates social cognition/overimitation in healthy adults, the meta-analysis requires fMRI studies, so exclude.

Abstract reports fMRI during naturalistic movie viewing and mentions adult comparison, but does not specify adult ages or whether the movie/task involves social-related processing. Eligibility requires at least one healthy adult group (17–65) and a social-related task. Information is insufficient from the abstract alone, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and task relevance.

fMRI study of affective Theory of Mind (social cognition: perception/understanding of others) in healthy participants (n=21). Task-based fMRI directly addresses the review objective and it is not a review/meta-analysis. Ages not reported in the abstract — include for full-text verification of age range.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed tasks assessing romantic/affiliative interest (IAT and date-rating) and executive control; participants were healthy adult males in relationships; study examines social-affiliation processes and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of facial emotion recognition (social communication/perception) performed in 29 healthy subjects, directly addressing social-related processing. Abstract does not report participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility (17–65).

This is a resting-state fMRI study with adults with autism and matched controls; no social-related task was performed during scanning. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social processing, so it does not meet the review criteria.

fMRI study with 18 healthy subjects performing a social motor response learning task that involves inference about others' intentions/goals (frontal operculum/mirror system). Meets inclusion (fMRI, social-related processing, healthy participants). Age range not reported — include for full-text to confirm ages and details.

Abstract reports a neuroimaging study identifying brain correlates of interpersonal synchrony in participants who served as referents; task is social/affiliation-related and participants appear to be healthy adults. Imaging modality and exact ages not specified, so include for full-text verification.

Abstract reports simultaneous fMRI (Hyperscan) during an interactive social task (deception game), meeting the social-task requirement. However, participant age and health status are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion cannot be fully confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify that at least one group are healthy adults aged 17–65.

Original fMRI study investigating processing of social information in laughter (social communication/mentalizing). Task involves social-related processing and likely used human participants. Abstract does not state participant age/health, so not enough to exclude; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and ages.

EmpaToM is an fMRI task that independently manipulates empathy and Theory of Mind in healthy adult participants (N=90 and N=178), directly addressing social-related processing. The study reports neural and behavioral outcomes, is empirical (not a review), and fits inclusion criteria. Ages not explicitly stated in the abstract, but participants are described as adults; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

fMRI study examining social-cognitive processing of personal attribute evaluations (perception/understanding of self), with individual differences in healthy participants implied. Abstract does not specify ages but meets the review objective; insufficient details on age/sample warrant inclusion for full-text screening.

fMRI study in healthy adult humans (N=55 males) performing a social-related task (direct vs. averted gaze), measuring amygdala BOLD response. Meets inclusion criteria (social processing, healthy adults). Not a review. Pharmacological/genetic features do not exclude inclusion.

Resting-state fMRI study without participants performing a social-related task. Although healthy controls are included, the meta-analysis requires task-based fMRI during social processing; abstract therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.
All participants were children (ages 7–12). Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65, which is not met. Study is not a review.

Resting-state fMRI in male adolescents with conduct disorder (patient group); no task-based social-processing paradigm and participants are adolescents rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet the review’s requirement for task-based social-related fMRI in healthy adult participants.

The study reports MEG (magnetoencephalography) hyperscanning with dual MEG recordings, not functional MRI. It therefore does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan during social-related tasks.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining perception of others’ social interactions (third-person perspective) using biological motion; task involves social-related processing (responses to typical vs atypical social actions). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.
