fMRI study in 22 healthy adult participants examining processing of CT-targeted affective (social) touch; task assesses social perception/cognition (insula, STS, mPFC), matches inclusion criteria and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in schizophrenia patients; no task-based fMRI of social processing is reported, and it does not focus on healthy adults performing a social-related task. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI BOLD study of affective and cognitive Theory of Mind (social cognition) in 23 healthy participants fits review objective of social-related processing in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient evidence of task-based fMRI in healthy humans; include for full-text extraction.

fMRI study investigating neural responses to observing social interactions and gaze, addressing social cognition/perception of others. Participants are human (presumably healthy adults); task is social-related. Not a review. Abstract lacks explicit age range, but criteria permit inclusion for full-text confirmation; include for full-text review.

The study used resting-state fMRI after cTBS rather than an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Although action observation/execution was used to localize the target, the primary data are resting-state connectivity, so it does not meet the task-based social fMRI inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports fMRI changes related to an implied social presence but does not state that participants performed a social-related task or provide participant ages/health. Information is insufficient to determine eligibility from abstract alone; include for full-text review to assess task details and participant characteristics.
Animal (rat) study using resting-state fMRI under anesthesia; not conducted in human participants and does not involve a social-task fMRI in healthy adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract addresses Theory of Mind (social cognition) relevant to review but does not specify that an fMRI was conducted or report participant characteristics (healthy adults, ages). Insufficient methodological detail to determine eligibility — include for full-text review.

fMRI study examines social-related processing (empathy/attachment—self, loved-one, stranger perspectives) using task-based imaging. Appears to involve healthy adult participants; not a review. Abstract lacks explicit age/health details, so include for full-text verification.

fMRI was conducted in healthy adult medical doctors (ages 25–37) during a social interaction task (doctor–patient treatment) probing empathy/compassion and reward-related processing, matching the review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review article.

Double-blind placebo-controlled fMRI in 55 healthy young men (within 17–65) using social-related stimuli (attachment-related erotic scenes and fearful social scenes). Study examines social processing and neural activation; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants performed a social-cognitive task about kin and friends, which fits the review objective. The abstract does not report participant ages, but includes healthy adults; no exclusion criteria apply. Include for full-text review to confirm ages and other details.

fMRI study comparing self-reference vs reference to others—directly addresses social cognition. Abstract describes task-based fMRI in human participants and is not a review. Participant health/age not specified; per guidance, include for full-text review when unclear.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (mothers) performing a social-related task (viewing own vs. unfamiliar child/dog) probing affiliation/attachment and social cognition. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI study using the Eyes task assessing theory of mind/social cognition, which fits the social-related task criterion. However the abstract does not state participant ages or clearly indicate a healthy adult group (17–65). Insufficient details to exclude; include for full-text review to confirm participant age and health status.

Study uses fMRI to examine self- and other-reflection (social processing) but abstract does not specify presence of a healthy control group. Include for full-text review to confirm whether healthy adults (age 17–65) were scanned.

Double-blind randomized crossover fMRI study in 18 healthy adult males performing a validated social cognition (Theory of Mind; Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test) task. Fits inclusion criteria (fMRI during social-related task in healthy adults); not a review.

Study used fMRI while participants performed a gaze-following task (a social attention/Perception of Others paradigm) investigating group/in‑group effects and ideological attitudes. It involves human voters (presumably healthy adults) and is an original empirical study, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI was used while participants (including a matched healthy adult control group) thought about social interactions—a social-related task addressing self/other representation. Participants are adults and healthy controls are present, meeting inclusion criteria. Not a review.

Study uses fMRI to examine Theory of Mind (a social cognition task) comparing euthymic bipolar patients with healthy subjects, indicating presence of a healthy adult control group and a social-related fMRI task. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants performed a social perception task examining in-group vs out-group bias in action perception, directly targeting social-related processing (perception of others). Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

Task-based fMRI study examining theory-of-mind/social cognition during cooperation vs. competition—clearly a social-related task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages not specified in the abstract, the study appears to involve healthy adult participants; meets inclusion for fMRI social processing. Include for full-text data extraction.

Participants were patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment and no healthy adult control group is reported. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants (age 17–65). Although the task involves face-name social stimuli, the absence of healthy participants excludes the study.

fMRI study probing empathy for others’ pain (social cognition). Includes a healthy young participant group aged 20–30, which meets the 17–65 inclusion age criterion. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

fMRI study investigating social brain connectivity and social symptom correlations; includes a group of typically developing (healthy) adolescents. However, ages are unspecified (adolescents may be <17), and inclusion criterion requires healthy adults 17–65. Abstract insufficient to confirm adult ages, so include for full-text review.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no task) investigating cerebro-cerebellar limbic networks in AD/MCI. It does not involve task-based social processing in healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in 18 healthy subjects investigating perspective-taking/empathy (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Meets inclusion of social-related task and healthy participants; not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study of perception/understanding of others (observing goal-directed hand actions) involving healthy participants (n=31). This is a social-perception task and includes a healthy adult group, meeting inclusion criteria. Age range not specified in abstract but likely adults; full text can confirm if needed.

Study used fMRI during a social/mentalizing task (Domino interactive task) and includes a typically developed healthy control group aged 18–34, meeting the review’s age and healthy-participant criteria. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study investigating processing of dynamic vs static facial expressions (social perception) and includes age- and sex-matched typically developing control group. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65), so insufficient info to confirm age criterion; include for full-text review to verify age and other details.

Abstract reports an event-related fMRI study using dynamic naturalistic videos contrasting social vs. nonsocial gestures, directly addressing social processing. No indication it is a review/meta-analysis. Participant health/ages are not specified in the abstract; therefore include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult (17–65) group and other eligibility details.

Abstract reports an fMRI study manipulating sociality and social working memory (social cognition/face processing). It addresses social-related processing in humans. Participant health/ages aren’t specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm at least one healthy adult group (17–65).

Study participants are adolescents (typically developing and TBI groups), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. Although it uses an fMRI social cognition task, the healthy group is under the target age range, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of self-referential processing (social-related: perception/understanding of self) that includes a healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages; insufficient to confirm they fall within 17–65. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and other methodological details.

fMRI study measuring Theory of Mind (a social cognitive task) with both bipolar patients and a healthy-control group (n=25). This meets the requirement of an fMRI social-related task and includes healthy adult participants; not a review.

fMRI study using MVPA examining neural organization of mental-state representation (social cognition: understanding others). Human participants implied; not a review. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study in human participants examining mirror neuron activity and the influence of emotional valence on visuomotor associations, addressing social cognition/perception of others. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original empirical study (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

Participants were healthy children/adolescents aged 10–17 with no adult (17–65) group reported. The meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65, so the study does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are preschool-aged children with ASD (and TD controls), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Although task is social-related, the sample does not include healthy adult participants, so it fails the age/group inclusion criterion.

Event-related fMRI study of moral reasoning (a social-cognitive task) with a matched group of 28 healthy subjects. Meets inclusion criteria (social-related fMRI in healthy adults); not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study using a joint-attention social task examining representation of what another person sees—clearly assesses social cognition/perception of others in humans. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and does not meet any exclusion criteria. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of body-checking/self-perception (relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’) but does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because the presence of healthy participants is unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with 26 participants performing empathy-evoking film clips addressing social cognition (empathic concern, integration of contextual emotional information). Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages/health, but it clearly meets the review's topic and should be included for full-text review to confirm age range and healthy sample.

This is a protocol for a systematic review/meta-analysis of oxytocin fMRI studies, not an original fMRI study with human participants performing a social-related task. Per exclusion criteria, systematic reviews/meta-analyses are excluded.

Sample comprises 9–17-year-olds (N=34); no separate adult group within the review’s required 17–65 age range is reported. Although an fMRI social task was used, the participants are adolescents, not the healthy adults targeted by the review.

Empirical fMRI study with 20 healthy adult volunteers performing a social-related task (simulating a boxer's feelings), investigating perception/understanding of others via action-observation network. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

The study used fMRI (dual‑fMRI) during cooperative and competitive social interactions, directly addressing social processing. The abstract does not specify participant age or explicitly state participants were healthy adults, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full‑text review to verify health status and age range.

fMRI study in healthy adults examining understanding of actions at different levels (why/how) that engages mental-state reasoning and action-representation networks; this probes social-cognitive processing (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining mentalizing (social cognition) during tasks about self/other; includes a healthy adult control group (33 age- and IQ-matched controls). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test, a social-cognitive task assessing perception/understanding of others. Sample comprises healthy young adult women (N=16) within the 17–65 range. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Original BOLD fMRI study examining social-related processing (affiliation vs isolation) while participants made pleasantness judgments. Involves healthy younger and older adult groups (younger adults likely within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study in healthy young adults using an incentive delay task with social rewards; directly examines neural correlates of social reward processing (anticipation and feedback), meeting the review’s population and task criteria. Not a review article.

fMRI study of facial perception and expression processing in human observers—fits social perception/communication objective. Likely healthy adults; abstract lacks explicit ages/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study used task-free (resting-state) fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Although the ATL is discussed in relation to social cognition, no social-related task was performed; thus it does not meet the requirement for fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants (single group) performing face and voice perception tasks, which are social-communication/perception of others constructs. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in normal adult volunteers viewing dynamic social interactions (positive/negative social encounters). This meets the social-related task criterion and includes healthy adults (normal volunteers). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Original fMRI study where participants performed a social task (sex-categorization of interacting person dyads). Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant age/health, so insufficient to confirm but meets the review topic; include for full-text review.

This is an fMRI study of face processing (social perception/understanding of others) with a healthy control group (21 adults) performing encoding/recognition of faces during scanning. It meets the review’s requirement for social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Age range not specified in abstract—full text can confirm ages if needed.

Participants are adult male incarcerated offenders; abstract does not report any healthy control group or healthy participants aged 17–65. Although it used task-based fMRI of social processing, inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (40 heterosexual males) examining neural and behavioral responses to interpersonal touch (a social/affiliative communication task). It reports task-related neural activity and behavioral outcomes relevant to social processing and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in healthy adult men during social-related tasks (face/gaze processing; theory of mind and fear-recognition), matching the review objective and inclusion criteria. Not a review/meta-analysis. Sufficient detail in abstract to include for full-text data extraction.

The study reports fMRI in a developmental sample of children and adolescents with no adult group aged 17–65; therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult (17–65) participant group.

This is an fMRI study in healthy human participants (N=25) examining facial color processing, which informs social communication and perception of others—directly relevant to the review’s social-related processing constructs. No exclusion criteria met. Although the abstract does not state participants’ ages explicitly, the study appears to involve typical adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm ages and other details.

fMRI study in healthy volunteers examining evaluative processes of guilt and embarrassment (social/self-conscious emotions), which fits social-related processing in adults; not a review. Age range not stated but participants described as healthy volunteers—include for full-text to confirm ages and details.
Participants are preadolescent children (age 11), falling well below the required adult age range (17–65) for inclusion in this review of healthy adult fMRI studies.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of social understanding in high-functioning adults; includes a healthy adult control group (n=23). Participants are adults and the task involves social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis—meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measured brain activity during a social interactive task versus a non-social control, addressing social cognition in humans. Participants appear to be healthy adults (no clinical populations reported), but ages are not specified in the abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.
All participants described are individuals with schizophrenia (AT+SCT N=11, CG N=11); no healthy adult group is reported. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65.

Abstract reports an fMRI mentalizing (social) task but does not state inclusion of a healthy control group aged 17–65; comparison group are nonpsychotic offenders (uncertain health status). Insufficient information to confirm presence of healthy adults, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Study used fMRI to measure neural responses during a social reflection task (judgments about self and others) in 22 healthy subjects, directly matching the review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although exact ages not reported in abstract, participants are described as healthy (likely adults); include for full-text if age needs confirmation.

Abstract reports effects of intranasal oxytocin on face processing in adults with Asperger syndrome only; it does not mention any healthy control group or inclusion of healthy participants (age 17–65). Fails the requirement of at least one healthy participant group.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of agentic self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluations (perception/understanding of self), which fits social-related processing. Abstract reports whole-brain fMRI analyses and trait self-esteem associations; implies healthy adult sample though ages not specified. No exclusion criteria met; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

Event-related fMRI study in human subjects assessing trustworthiness judgments of faces (perception/understanding of others), a social processing task. Not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) demographics.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in human participants using a social interaction task (cyber-ball) manipulating social inclusion/exclusion and testing neural responses to partners' faces. This fits social processing in healthy adults; not a review. Sufficient information in abstract to include for full-text review.

Hyperscanning fMRI was used during a real-time joint-attention social interaction, directly addressing social processing. The study involves human dyads and validates cross-brain connectivity related to social behavior; it is empirical (not a review) and likely uses healthy adult participants. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining self-recognition (face and name), which is a social-related construct (Perception/Understanding of Self). Methods and population match inclusion criteria and it is an original research article, not a review.

Abstract describes an fMRI study probing social perception/understanding (mirror and mentalizing networks) using interaction stimuli. It appears to involve human participants and addresses social processing. Participant ages/health not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy adults criterion.

Title and methods indicate a multilevel kernel density fMRI analysis (MKDA), a coordinate-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI experiment with participants. The exclusion criteria rule out meta-analyses/systematic reviews.

Participants are children with benign childhood epilepsy (BCECTS) undergoing fMRI; no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported. Thus it does not meet the requirement of including healthy adults 17–65.

The abstract investigates VLPFC white-matter and functional networks supporting memory retrieval using fMRI and diffusion imaging. It does not describe any social-related task or construct (e.g., affiliation, social communication, self/other perception). Therefore it does not meet the review’s inclusion criterion of fMRI during a social-related task.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using social interaction images (social-context emotional stimuli) and includes remitted depressed participants alongside healthy controls (adult sample). It is original research (not a review) and meets criteria for social-related fMRI tasks with healthy adult participants.

Functional MRI was used while participants viewed cooperative vs noncooperative social interactions (a social cognition/theory-of-mind task). The study includes a healthy matched control group (19 adults) alongside patients, and is not a review. Information in the abstract is sufficient to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract does not mention any fMRI imaging; study focuses on autism spectrum conditions and atypical imitation rather than clearly including a healthy adult group (17–65). Lacks required evidence of fMRI in healthy participants.

Study reports fMRI of emotion recognition but includes only schizophrenia outpatients (no healthy participant group). Inclusion requires at least one healthy group aged 17–65, so exclude based on participant population.

fMRI study examining social processes (mimicry, affiliation, group membership, emotional expression). Meets review objective of social-related processing. Abstract does not state participant age/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

fMRI was used during perception of nonverbal emotional social signals (voice and face), a social-related task tapping social communication and perception of others. The abstract implies healthy participants; age range not specified. Include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and other details.

Study uses fMRI with a social-related face-processing task (dynamic social stimuli). Abstract focuses on schizophrenia patients but does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because the abstract is insufficient to confirm presence of healthy participants, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.
Participants are adolescents aged 12–15 with no adult (17–65) healthy group. Although it is an fMRI social-exclusion study, it fails the age eligibility criterion for the review.

fMRI was acquired while healthy participants read a narrative and rated experienced suspense; reported activations are in medial frontal and temporo-parietal regions linked to social cognition and predictive inference. This constitutes social-related processing (perception/understanding of others) in a healthy adult sample, meeting inclusion criteria.

Hyperscanning fMRI was used while participants performed joint-attention tasks probing social cognition/understanding of others. The study investigates social processing in humans and is not a review. Participants appear to be healthy adults; thus it meets the fMRI + social task and healthy participant inclusion criteria.

The study used near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) rather than functional MRI. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan during a social-related task; despite involving healthy adults and a social conversation task, the imaging modality does not meet the criterion.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than scanning participants while they performed a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during a social processing task; therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a review article of seven structural and functional MRI studies in ADHD samples (clinical population, likely children/adolescents), not a primary fMRI study of healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews and does not report fMRI of healthy 17–65 participants.

fMRI study investigating person perception and impression updating (social cognition). Participants performed a social task (faces paired with behavioral info). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract implies healthy adult participants; age not listed but criterion allows inclusion if unclear—include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

fMRI hyperscanning study of mutual eye contact in healthy adult pairs; task probes social interaction/perception processes (eye contact, affective/mental state sharing). Participants are healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI was used while participants completed a social-related task (implicit attitudes toward politicians, face/name processing). Results concern social cognition (perception/understanding of others, affiliation). Participants appear to be healthy adults; no review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for meta-analysis.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants investigating co-speech gestures—an aspect of social communication—while watching a narrator; directly examines social-related processing and is empirical (not a review).

Abstract does not report any fMRI data or a social-processing task. It examines gene–environment interactions on response inhibition in adolescents, not a social-related fMRI study in healthy adults (ages 17–65).

Abstract reports an fMRI study addressing self-experience and self-other relationship (social cognition) and includes a healthy control group. However, it does not state whether imaging was acquired during a social-related task or at rest (mentions intrinsic/background connectivity). Insufficient information in abstract to confirm task-based social processing; include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract describes methodological network analysis and differences related to psychosis risk; it does not report an fMRI social-related task or social processing measures. Not focused on social cognition/interaction, so does not meet the review objective.

Resting-state fMRI study with no social-related task performed. Although the abstract mentions networks related to social cognition, it does not involve a task probing social processing. Participants include a clinical (obese) group and lean controls, but lack of task-based social paradigm clearly fails the inclusion criterion.

fMRI study examining perception of different laughter types—clearly social communication/social-cognition processing in humans. No psychiatric/neurological disorders reported. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and other details.

fMRI study (N=26) examining social learning about others’ generosity versus a non-social control; directly addresses social processing. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI was used while adult participants viewed dynamic emotional facial expressions (social perception/understanding of others). The study includes a healthy control group (adults) and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

All participants were individuals with a psychotic disorder (patients); no healthy control group is reported. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adults (17–65). Although fMRI social tasks were used, the absence of healthy participants excludes the study.

Participants are boys (children), not adults; the healthy control is a typically developing boy rather than adults aged 17–65. The study focuses on autism cases and single-case comparisons, not fMRI in healthy adults performing social tasks, so it fails the age/group inclusion criterion.

fMRI study with ‘normal subjects’ performing a social communication task (communicative speech vs description), investigating brain regions involved in social interaction/communication. Fits inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy participants aged likely 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition) in healthy adult participants (n=19). Task involved social-related processing (mental state inference and contextual adjustments). Participants are healthy adults within the eligible age range. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Narrative comparative review of face perception across species; not an original human fMRI study. Abstract discusses behavioral and comparative literature rather than reporting fMRI in healthy adult participants performing a social task, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes original fMRI experiments using the Why/How Task to probe Theory of Mind (perception/understanding of others), involving human participants across three studies. It is not a review/meta-analysis and targets social cognition in presumably healthy adults, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examines cortical responses to vocal (social) vs nonvocal sounds and compares individuals with autism to a normal activation pattern, implying a healthy control group. It addresses social-related auditory processing. Abstract does not state participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and other eligibility details.

Participants are children/adolescents (young adolescents) including an autism group and typically developing adolescents; no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported. Therefore it does not meet the requirement of at least one healthy adult participant group.

Human fMRI study examining perception of social signals (facial expressions and social approach), clearly addressing social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). No indication study is a review or involves only clinical populations; likely healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Study used resting-state fMRI to assess biomarkers in individuals with autism; no task-based social processing paradigm described and focus is clinical ASD rather than healthy adults performing social tasks.
Participants are children and adolescents (ages 8–17). No adult-only group within the required 17–65 age range is reported, so the study does not meet the adult participant criterion for inclusion.
This is a resting-state fMRI study in ultra-high-risk (clinical) subjects with no task-based social processing reported and no clear healthy adult task group; does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during a face-perception task with emotional/neutral stimuli (social cognition/perception of others) and includes a healthy control group alongside social phobia patients. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age not reported in abstract—include for full-text verification.

Resting-state fMRI was used (no social-related task). Inclusion requires a task-based social processing paradigm; although healthy adults and oxytocin/social cognition are relevant, absence of a social task excludes the study.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social perception comparing ASD and typically developing adolescents, involving social-related tasks and healthy (typically developing) participants. However, participant ages are not specified in the abstract, so it is unclear whether healthy participants fall within the 17–65 range. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and other eligibility details.

fMRI study examining processing of social reputation (social-related task) in male and female subjects; appears to involve healthy adult participants and targets social cognition (vmPFC responses). No exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study in 20 healthy human participants performing a social-related mimicry task modulated by eye contact. Directly examines social processing (mimicry, eye contact) in healthy adults and is an original empirical study (not a review). Ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

Abstract reports neural activation during social cognitive tasks in patients and their unaffected siblings, implying inclusion of healthy adults (unaffected siblings) and social-related processing; likely used fMRI though not explicitly stated. Abstract lacks explicit mention of fMRI, so include for full-text review to confirm methods and participant ages.
Participants are non-human (dogs); review requires fMRI studies in human adults (age 17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Primary fMRI study with 28 healthy adult participants performing a social interaction simulation probing friendship (affiliation/empathy/reward). Task is social-related; adults within target age range; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

The study addresses social perception (evaluation of face approachability), fitting the review objective. However the abstract does not explicitly state that fMRI was used or specify participant ages/health. Include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and healthy adult sample.

Provides fMRI data collected while healthy adult participants performed social-related tasks (emotion discrimination and affective priming involving facial/vocal expressions). Addresses social communication and perception of others; not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining neural representations of empathy for familiar vs unfamiliar others in (presumably) healthy adult participants; task is social (empathy/other perception). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI during social cognition tasks (empathy, forgivability) but does not state presence of a healthy control/group of healthy adults. Insufficient information to confirm required healthy participant group; include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

The healthy participant group comprises typically developing adolescents (ages 12–19); no healthy adult sample within the required 17–65 age range is reported. Thus it does not meet the inclusion criterion of a healthy participant group aged 17–65.

Human functional MRI study investigating affiliative/kinship-related social scenarios. Abstract indicates neuroimaging of affiliative emotion in humans (presumably healthy adult participants) and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of 36 healthy human subjects performing a social-related task (observing cooperative and affective social interactions) addressing perception/understanding of others. Participants are healthy adults; study is original empirical fMRI research, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

The article is a meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI studies. The exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded despite addressing social-related fMRI tasks in healthy adults.

The study used resting-state fMRI (ALFF and RSFC) to examine trait self-esteem and did not involve participants performing a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during a social-related task; thus it should be excluded.

fMRI study focuses on children (high-functioning ASD vs typically developing children), not adults. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65. Therefore it does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

fMRI study of prayer in a group of (presumably healthy) adult Danish Christians; task (praying) engages social-cognition regions (mPFC, TPJ, precuneus), fitting ‘perception/understanding of others’ social processing. Meets fMRI + social-task + healthy adult group criteria. Age range not stated but participants described as a general adult group; include for full-text review.

Abstract discusses brain activation related to social cognition but does not explicitly state that fMRI was used or whether a healthy control group (ages 17–65) was included. Information is insufficient from the abstract alone, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study of social processing (learning others' trustworthiness) in healthy younger and older adults. Younger group likely falls within 17–65, meeting inclusion; no exclusion criteria met and abstract clearly reports task-based fMRI of social cognition.

Event-related fMRI using a false-belief task probes understanding of others’ mental states (social cognition). Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health explicitly; include for full-text review to confirm that healthy adults (17–65) were studied and to extract details.

Abstract reports use of real-time fMRI combined with EEG to train social communication skills targeting the right STS, addressing social-related processing. However, participant characteristics (healthy adults aged 17–65) and task details are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

All participant groups are children (unaffected siblings, children with ASD, matched control children); no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported. Although fMRI and a social task were used, the age criterion for healthy adults is not met.
fMRI study where participants performed a virtual social cognition task (perception/understanding of others) and included a healthy control group of adults (14 controls). Not a review.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based fMRI during a social-related task. Although it concerns oxytocin and social-affective processes in healthy adults, it does not meet the requirement of participants performing a social-related task during scanning.
Participants are adolescents (mean ages 15.8 and 16.2), which falls below the required adult age range of 17–65; therefore no eligible adult healthy participant group is present.

The study reports fMRI during an affective theory-of-mind task but includes only 25 unmedicated patients with chronic depression; the abstract does not report any healthy control or healthy participant group (age 17–65). Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group.

fMRI study using a trustworthiness ratings task (social perception of others). Abstract indicates neural mechanisms of race disparities in social cognition; meets review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria met and abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text review.

Abstract reports simultaneous fMRI during live verbal interaction between pairs of (healthy) female friends, addressing social communication. This fits the review’s focus on fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults. While exact ages aren’t reported, participants are described as adult friends; full text can confirm demographics.

fMRI study investigating neural correlates of verbal irony comprehension (a social-communication/Theory-of-Mind task). Participants appear to be healthy adults; task involves perception/understanding of others’ intentions. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Primary empirical fMRI study of social (eye-gaze) processing; includes a group of typically developing (healthy) subjects alongside autism group; task probes social cognition (intentions via gaze). Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using attributional decision tasks probing self-responsibility and the self-serving bias (social cognition: perception/understanding of self/others). Abstract reports ‘normal subjects,’ indicating healthy human participants. Directly addresses social-related processing with functional MRI — meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social-evaluation (peer watching) with child, adolescent, and adult participants; task is clearly social/self-related. Although exact adult ages and explicit statement of participant health are not provided, the study likely includes healthy adults. Insufficient detail on ages/health in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study used resting-state fMRI (fALFF) rather than functional MRI during a social-related task. Inclusion requires fMRI while participants performed a social task; the abstract does not report task-based fMRI, so exclude based on not meeting the primary inclusion criterion.

fMRI study using an adaptive emotion recognition task (social cognition: perception/understanding of others) with a healthy control group (n=16). Participants are adults and task is social-related. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study using a social contingency task assessing self-relevant social reward processing; includes a healthy (typically developing) adult control group matched on age/IQ. Participants are adults, meeting the 17–65 range. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study addressing decoding of vocal emotional expressions—a social communication/perception task—meets the review objective. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65).
Study used EEG to measure mu rhythm, not functional MRI. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan during a social-related task; therefore it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

fMRI was acquired while participants performed multiple-round trust games (a social-processing task). The study includes a healthy control group (20 adults) alongside patients, and addresses social reward/trust (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient basis for inclusion for full-text data extraction.

Event-related fMRI study in humans examining person perception/social expectation violations; participants performed a social task (forming impressions using political affiliation/views). No indication of clinical populations or that this is a review. Fits ‘social-related processing in healthy adults’ criterion; include for full-text review to confirm sample ages and health status.

The study used fMRI during a social-processing task (direct vs. averted gaze) and included a group of healthy adult participants (n=16), meeting inclusion criteria. It is an original research article, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Abstract reports fMRI responses to moral sentiments (e.g., subgenual cingulate responses to guilt) and relates these to grey matter volumes in healthy adults during an experimental task assessing moral emotions (social processing). Therefore it appears to involve fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm details.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants using a social interaction task (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) involving perception of angry vs. neutral facial expressions; examines social signal processing (OFC/ACC) in healthy adults. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining event simulation including social-cognitive processes (mentalizing/trait inference), which fits ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. The abstract implies healthy adult participants in task-based fMRI. No exclusion criteria met, and the abstract provides sufficient relevance for full-text review.

Participants are pediatric/youth (unaffected youth at familial risk and patients with pediatric bipolar disorder), not healthy adults aged 17–65. The study therefore does not meet the age requirement for inclusion.

The abstract explicitly states this is a review of neuroimaging experiments (fMRI/PET) rather than an original fMRI study with primary human participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses; no participant/sample or task data are reported.

Abstract reports an fMRI task (viewing social scenes) measuring dmPFC responses related to mentalizing/social behavior in daily life. This addresses social-related processing in humans and is empirical (not a review). Participant health/age not specified, but inclusion favored when abstract lacks details—include for full-text review.

fMRI conducted while healthy adult participants (young volunteers) performed a social task: labeling brief emotional facial expressions (perception/understanding of others). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract provides insufficient information to confirm that an fMRI social-task was performed with a healthy adult group (ages 17–65). Title suggests ASD focus and social cognition networks, so the full text should be checked for healthy control participants and task details. Include for full-text review.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social task (gaze following/processing others' social attention); directly examines social perception neural mechanisms. Not a review article; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using biological motion perception (a social-perception task) in adults and youth; reports results in healthy participants with adult group included. Not a review/meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Full text review recommended to confirm exact adult age range and participant health status.

fMRI study of affect matching to fearful/angry faces—a social processing task (perception/understanding of others). Includes a healthy comparison group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient evidence of relevance; full text can confirm participant ages if needed.

The study examines large-scale brain network community structure during rest and task states, without any mention of social-related tasks or social processing constructs. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion of an fMRI study involving social-related task performance in healthy adults.

Primary empirical fMRI study scanning participants during encoding of social messages and subsequent influence behavior (mentalizing/reward systems). This addresses social communication/understanding of others in humans; not a review. Participant health/age not explicitly stated but typical adult sample and no disorder groups mentioned—meets inclusion. Recommend full-text for confirmation of age range and health status.

fMRI study where participants made charitable donation decisions—clearly a social decision-making task (altruism/attachment). Involves human participants and neural measures; not a review. Abstract does not specify ages, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

Participants are adolescents aged 11–16 (boys), not within the required adult age range (17–65). Therefore the study does not include healthy adult participants and does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of neural responses to facial expressions (social/emotional processing). Includes healthy participant groups (unaffected siblings and healthy controls), and is an original empirical study, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in adults.

fMRI conducted during a social-related task (facial emotion and age judgments). Study includes a healthy community control group (presumably adult controls within typical 17–65 range). Not a review or meta-analysis. Therefore meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating perception of socially relevant facial expressions (social communication) in human participants; not a review. Abstract implies healthy adult participants and directly addresses social processing. Participant age/health not fully specified, so include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study of healthy young adults performing a social attribution task (perception of human-like interactions), directly assessing social cognition. Participants are healthy and within target age range; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of healthy participants (n=25) performing prosocial decisions toward family — a clear social-related task (prosocial behavior, mentalizing, self-control). Participants appear to be adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

Participants are described as early adolescents (male and female adolescents), not adults; no group within the required 17–65 age range. Although it uses fMRI and examines social cognition, the age criterion for inclusion is not met.

Resting-state fMRI study with no social-related task; inclusion requires task-based fMRI assessing social processing. Although it includes healthy adults, the scan was conducted at rest, so it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

fMRI study where participants performed a social task (making a listener laugh) probing self- and other-related processing (mPFC, auditory cortex, ventral striatum). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is empirical primary research, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in a typical (healthy adult) sample performing a social-cognitive task (attributing causes to self, other, or situation). This addresses perception/understanding of self and others, uses functional MRI, and is not a review—meets inclusion criteria based on the abstract.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult male participants performing a social-related task (watching empathy-eliciting campaign videos). Assesses neural correlates of social cognition (empathy, perception/understanding of others; STS activation). Not a review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of cooperative decision making (Ultimatum Game), a social-related task (affiliation/attachment, social cooperation). It uses a healthy sample in a randomized longitudinal design (mindfulness vs active control). Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.
Participants were children aged 7–10 only; the review requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65. No adult group is reported, so the study does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

Participants were children aged 7–12 with and without ASD; no healthy adult (17–65) group is included. Although an fMRI movie task assesses social cognition, the study does not meet the age criterion for healthy adults required by the review.

fMRI study investigating visual short-term memory for emotional (angry) faces — a social perception/communication task involving face identity and emotion. Involves human participants (healthy adults likely). No exclusion criteria met; aligns with review objective.

Study used fMRI during an interactive competitive reaction-time task probing social interaction and reactive aggression in sixteen healthy adult male participants, directly addressing social processing (understanding others, affective response). Participants are healthy adults and this is original research (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports use of eyetracking during functional MRI to create gaze-contingent, interactive social paradigms and reviews results from two paradigms—indicating fMRI social-task data in humans. Participant health status and ages are not reported in the abstract, so full text is needed to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65).

fMRI study with healthy adult participants viewing racial ingroup/outgroup faces—constitutes social processing (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and other eligibility details.

fMRI study examining audiovisual integration of non‑verbal emotional signals (social communication/perception), matching review objective. Abstract does not specify participant age/health status; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65) and other eligibility details.

fMRI study of social-emotional face processing that reports comparisons with control participants. Abstract indicates healthy controls but does not state ages (17–65). Include for full-text review to confirm that at least one healthy adult group falls within the age range and meets criteria.

fMRI study examining processing of others' behavior (social cognition). Participants observed social interactions; task clearly social. Abstract implies healthy adult participants though ages not specified. Insufficient participant age/health detail in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
Resting-state fMRI (no social task) and sample are adolescent males rather than adults (17–65). Does not meet the requirement for task-based social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of anticipation of others' actions (perception/understanding of others), conducted in human players (healthy participants across skill levels). Task is social-related (action observation/anticipation). Abstract contains no exclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

fMRI study of social processing (direct vs averted gaze) using a task probing social perception/communication; includes a healthy adult comparison group (n=16) within target age range; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=10) viewing funny vs non-funny cartoons; humor appreciation relates to social communication/perception. Abstract does not clearly state social-cognitive task but provides insufficient detail to rule out relevance—include for full-text review to confirm social-related processing and participant ages.

The study reports fMRI in 17 young adults with high-functioning ASD only; the abstract does not mention any healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65).

Study uses fMRI to examine perception of biological motion (a social perception task). Abstract only mentions OCD patients and does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information in abstract — include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy participants.

Study uses fMRI during emotional face viewing, a social perception task (Perception/Understanding of Others). Reports data from male and female participants (implies healthy adults) and is an original empirical study, not a review. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health status.

The study used fMRI to compare mothers’ brain responses to emotional expressions of their own children—an attachment/social-affiliation task—in adult participants. Participants appear to be healthy adults (mothers), fitting the 17–65 range. Abstract indicates original fMRI data (not a review). Include for full-text review to confirm ages and health status.

fMRI study using a face discrimination task (social perception) and includes a healthy adult control group (age-matched adults), satisfying inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=16) involving incidental priming of personal promotion/prevention goals—addresses self-regulation and personal goal pursuit (perception/understanding of self), a social-related process. Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria. Abstract gives sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Event-related fMRI study investigating agency attribution from animated shapes—a social-perception/understanding task. Appears to involve healthy adult participants viewing animations; meets meta-analysis objective of social processing in healthy adults. Abstract does not specify ages but provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI was conducted while participants viewed stigmatized vs. control individuals (a social perception/understanding of others task). The study involves healthy young and older adults; although exact ages aren’t reported in the abstract, inclusion is warranted for full-text review to confirm age ranges and eligibility.

fMRI study of face identity and eye-gaze perception—addresses social communication/perception of others. Conducted in humans (presumably healthy adults). No exclusion criteria met. Abstract indicates relevant social-related task during fMRI.

Human fMRI study investigating empathic decision-making (social processing: perception/understanding of others). Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy status (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study sample comprises adolescents/youth (socially anxious and healthy youth), not adults. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65; the abstract indicates a youth/adolescent sample, so it does not meet the age criterion.

Event-related fMRI in healthy adult participants (registered Democrats and Republicans) while viewing and rating faces of political candidates — a social perception/understanding-of-others task. Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study directly investigates social communication (communicative vs noncommunicative vocalizations) in humans, matching the review objective. Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm that at least one group are healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study examining vicarious somatosensory responses during observation of touch—a social perception/understanding of others task. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is original research (not a review). Include for full-text review.

Abstract reports dyadic (live eye contact) fMRI comparing social interaction vs. face pictures, addressing social processing/perception of others. It describes BOLD responses in healthy-sounding participants; age/health status not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study of mirror neuron activity during observation of hand actions (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Includes both alexithymic and non-alexithymic adult participant groups (healthy controls present). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults; no exclusion criteria evident.

Task involves social decision-making (charitable donations) and reports fMRI data on regions linked to social cognition. Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Task-based fMRI was used to measure theory-of-mind (social cognition) in healthy younger and older adults; this addresses social-related processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age groups not fully detailed in abstract, but 'younger adults' likely fall within 17–65; include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study of social-related processing (affective meaning of touch/theory of mind/embodied resonance). Likely includes comparison between ASD and typical processing, but abstract does not explicitly state presence/ages of healthy controls. Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult group (17–65) and task details.

Healthy adult participants were scanned with fMRI while performing an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma (a social decision-making/trust task). The study examines social processing and neural correlates and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

The abstract reports an fMRI study in 37 healthy adult subjects performing a facial emotion recognition task (FEEL), which is a social communication/perception task. It meets the task-based fMRI and healthy adult inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria are met.

fMRI study of social processing (gaze direction) including a typically developing (healthy) comparison group. Abstract does not specify participant ages (adolescents and adults), so full text is needed to confirm that healthy participants fall within 17–65; include for full-text review.

Study reports an fMRI experiment in which healthy young and older adults (15 each) performed social impression-formation tasks. This addresses social processing and uses fMRI; includes a young healthy group likely within the 17–65 range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

Title indicates investigation of mentalizing and mirror neuron networks (social cognition) in ASD, likely using fMRI and likely including healthy control participants, but the abstract does not confirm task-based vs. resting-state fMRI or exact ages. Insufficient information to rule out inclusion — include for full-text review.

Participants are children (NVLD, ASD, and typically developing children); review requires healthy adults aged 17–65. The abstract does not report adult participants or an eligible healthy adult group, so it does not meet the population criterion.

The study uses resting-state fMRI (seed-based correlation) rather than a task-based social processing paradigm; participants appear to be identified during intraoperative cortical stimulation (clinical/patient context). Thus it does not meet the inclusion requirement of fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults.

This article is a review of pharmacological fMRI and imaging genetics findings, not an original fMRI study. It is a systematic review-type article, which meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

This paper is a systematic review of studies (25 papers) on the mirror neuron system in autism, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Original fMRI study examining empathy for others' pain (social cognition: perception/understanding of others) that includes healthy control participants. Adult sample likely; not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This article is a systematic review of fMRI and DTI studies in autism spectrum disorder, not a primary fMRI study in healthy adults. Exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses) is clearly met; participant group focuses on ASD patients rather than healthy 17–65-year-olds.

The article is a narrative review of the field (a secondary synthesis), not a primary fMRI study with original data on healthy adults performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and provides no evidence of relevant task-based fMRI results in healthy participants.
Participants are infants (4–7 months), not healthy adults aged 17–65 as required. The study does not include adult participants, so it does not meet the review’s population criterion.

fMRI study examining perception of own and others’ bodies in 15 male and 15 female healthy participants — task taps Perception/Understanding of Self and Others (social processing). Not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm age and other details.

Single-case study of an 8-year-old with massive bilateral frontal lesions; not a healthy adult sample (17–65) and does not report fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was used during a social-cognitive task (reflection on self and mother — perception/understanding of self and others). Participants are healthy Chinese adults. Study is empirical fMRI research (not a review) and matches the review’s social processing constructs; thus it meets inclusion criteria.

The healthy control group consists of adolescents aged 12–18; the review requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65 (adults). Thus the study does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

fMRI study examining impression formation (social cognition) with participants performing an ecologically meaningful social task; reports neural activity (dmPFC). No clinical population is indicated, implying healthy adult participants. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults; include for full-text review.

fMRI study on perception and production of prosody (social communication), examines neural processes and correlations with empathy in humans. Likely healthy adult participants; meets social-related task and healthy adult criteria. Not a review.
This article is explicitly a quantitative meta-analysis of fMRI studies (systematic/meta-analytic), and the exclusion criteria specify systematic reviews or meta-analyses should be excluded.

Abstract reports human fMRI using model-based analysis of social cognition (simulation of others' minds), matching the review objective. Participant health/ages are not specified, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify sample meets criteria.

Study used functional MRI during a social task (modified prisoner’s dilemma) and included a healthy control group (n=20) of adult participants. It directly investigates social processing and is not a review, meeting the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where participants engaged in cooperative vs. competitive social tasks—directly addresses social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract implies healthy adult participants; if age/health details are unclear, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract describes a systematic review integrating neuroimaging studies (a review/meta-analysis), which meets the exclusion criterion. It does not report primary fMRI data from healthy adults; thus excluded based on study type.

Abstract lacks methods and participant details: unclear whether an fMRI task was actually conducted and whether a healthy adult group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to exclude; include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining processing of goal-directed actions and intention perception (perception/understanding of others), which is a social cognitive task. Although abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, it is an empirical neuroimaging study likely with healthy adults; if unclear, include for full-text review.

fMRI study of perception of emotional gestures—a social communication/perception task—and includes a healthy control group alongside autism participants. Although ages aren’t specified in the abstract, the design fits the review objective; include for full-text review to confirm age range and details.

The abstract reports an fMRI experiment probing self-referential processing in intergroup competition (mPFC activation) and measures willingness to harm competitors — a social-related task in humans. It’s not a review. Participant ages/health aren’t specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm they are healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study scanning participants while they processed the social meaning of symbolic artifacts; reports activations in social-cognition regions (mPFC, TPJ, precuneus, insula). Involves healthy human participants performing a social-related task, meeting inclusion criteria. Age range not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and participant details.

This is a narrative review article synthesizing MRI findings across adolescence; it does not report original fMRI experiments of social processing in healthy adults. As a review/meta-analytic piece, it meets the exclusion criterion.

Abstract mentions neural correlates of mentalizing and brain structure but does not specify whether task-based fMRI was used or participant health/ages. Information is insufficient to determine eligibility from abstract alone—include for full-text review to confirm methods and sample.

fMRI study examining social processing (response to socially awkward situations) using healthy control participants alongside ASD group. Task is social and naturalistic. Not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm age and other eligibility details.

fMRI study of healthy adult participants performing social-related tasks (recognition of others' action 'vitality forms'—perception/understanding of others). Meets inclusion (functional MRI, social processing). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

This is a literature review of motor lateralization in autism (not an original fMRI study) and focuses on motor networks and ASD rather than social processing in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews and does not address the meta-analysis objective.

This study was conducted in non-human primates (monkeys) using fMRI with electrical microstimulation; it does not involve human participants (ages 17–65) performing a social-related task, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria for human fMRI studies.

fMRI study of social-related processing (integration of speaker characteristics with sentence content) relevant to social communication/understanding others; includes matched healthy adult control group. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract discusses brain network topology and emotional/social cognition but does not specify that a functional MRI task targeting social processing was used or participant ages. Insufficient methodological detail to determine eligibility from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (18 male non-musicians) performing an aesthetic-rating task. The artistic-music condition engaged ToM/mentalizing regions (PCC/PC, arMFC, TPJ) and was interpreted as involving cognitive empathy/social cognition, meeting the criterion of social-related processing during task.

Study used fMRI during an interpersonal pleasant-touch paradigm (a social reward task) and included a matched healthy non-using control group of adults. Thus it meets the fMRI social-processing task criterion and includes healthy participants.
Study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task). Although it included healthy controls, it did not involve participants performing a social processing task required for inclusion.

Abstract reports human neuroimaging of intranasal oxytocin effects on amygdala reactivity but does not specify whether a social-related task was used or participant health status. Information is insufficient to determine inclusion based on abstract alone, so include for full-text review to verify task and sample.

fMRI was acquired while participants recalled collective (social) memories, focusing on medial prefrontal cortex and social-cognitive schemas. It reports an original human fMRI experiment (not a review) with likely healthy adult participants. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI was used during an interactive social task (charades) investigating mirroring and mentalizing between gesturer and guesser. Participants are presumably healthy adults; study directly examines social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was used while participants made social judgments (empathy, forgivability), matching the review objective. Ten volunteers implies healthy adult participants. Abstract lacks explicit age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract describes multimodal biomarkers of cognitive deficits in schizophrenia using the MCCB; it does not report an fMRI social-processing task nor focus on healthy adult social processing. Participants appear to be schizophrenia patients; no evidence of healthy adult social task data. Therefore not eligible for review.

fMRI paradigm used face emotional processing, which is a social perception task relevant to the review. Abstract lacks information on participant health status and ages (17–65 requirement), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify sample characteristics.

This is a review/introduction to a special issue (review article) rather than an original fMRI study. The abstract reports a review of studies (including fMRI) and contains no original fMRI data in healthy adults, meeting the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Event-related fMRI in healthy adult participants investigated perception/understanding of others (empathy for pain) and social context/agency — a social-related task in healthy adults; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full review.

fMRI was conducted during passive viewing of natural movies, and analyses explicitly report voxel responses to ‘social communication’ categories. Participants appear to be healthy adults; abstract lacks ages, so include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and task details.

The article is a review of studies on social cognition in bipolar disorder (a review article), not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not provide primary fMRI data on healthy participants.

Abstract reports fMRI in a sample of 14 females with borderline personality disorder and discusses symptom severity; no healthy control or healthy participant group (age 17–65) is mentioned. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group. Although the task involves emotional/social cognition, absence of healthy participants warrants exclusion based on abstract alone.

fMRI was conducted during facial emotion processing, a social-related task (perception/understanding of others/social interaction). The study includes a healthy control group of adults. No exclusion criteria met in the abstract.

Study uses fMRI during social-evaluation/perspective-taking and includes a healthy comparison group. However, participants are described as adolescents and ages are not specified; full text needed to confirm healthy subjects fall within 17–65. Include for full-text review.

Study samples are pediatric (youth) participants rather than healthy adults aged 17–65, and the abstract does not indicate an fMRI social-processing task. Does not meet inclusion criteria for adult healthy participants and relevant task.

Original fMRI study probing social-emotional simulation/empathy (perception/understanding of others) using a task involving imagining another’s pain; includes a healthy adult control group (n=24). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining spontaneous retrieval of affective person knowledge during face perception — a social-cognition task in humans. Participants appear to be healthy adults, but ages are not reported in the abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm participant age range and health status.

Study examines fMRI development of the action observation network in early adolescence (participants are adolescents), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one adult (17–65) healthy participant group.

Abstract provides insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria. It reports an fMRI study of deception (a social-related task) in individuals with psychopathic traits but does not state whether a healthy adult group (age 17–65) was included. No exclusion criteria are met. Include for full-text review to determine participant health status, ages, and task details.

Event-related fMRI in 12 healthy volunteers performing self/familiar/unknown face judgments—addresses perception/understanding of self (social processing). Participants are healthy adults; meets inclusion criteria and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study using a threat-reactivity task with socially threatening images (social-related processing) and includes a healthy control group of age- and ethnicity-matched women with no cancer history. Although ages are not explicitly stated, participants are adults; the presence of a healthy adult control group satisfies inclusion criteria.

This is a methodological/review article about magnetoencephalography (MEG), not an fMRI study. The abstract does not report a functional MRI experiment or social-task data in healthy adults; it appears to be an overview/review rather than primary fMRI research.

fMRI study in 40 healthy volunteers viewing masked and unmasked emotional faces (social/affiliation-related processing). Meets inclusion: functional MRI during a social-related task and healthy adult participants. No exclusion criteria met. Age range not reported in abstract, but sufficient to include for full-text review.

Abstract describes MRI-based classification of ASD vs controls using the ABIDE dataset; it does not report an fMRI social-related task or social-processing paradigm, and participant ages are not specified as healthy adults 17–65.
