This is a narrative review of perceptual organization in schizophrenia, not an original fMRI study. It does not report functional MRI scans during social-related tasks in healthy adults; thus it fails the primary inclusion criterion. Exclude.

Study used fMRI during a social cognition task (adapted Reading-the-Mind-in-the-Eyes Task) and included a healthy non-offender control group (H). Participants are adult men and the study is original research, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing studies with healthy adults.

Study 2 used fMRI to measure neural responses (mPFC, PCC, temporal poles) during viewing of sexualized and clothed men/women, a social-perception/mental-state attribution task in healthy adult participants (heterosexual men). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

The healthy control group comprises adolescents aged 13–19 (includes minors <17). The review requires at least one healthy adult group aged 17–65; this study’s sample is adolescent, not adult, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in which participants performed a social-closeness task (photos of friends vs unknown people), directly addressing social-related processing. It is not a review/meta-analysis. Participant health/ages are not specified in the abstract — include for full-text to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study manipulating interpersonal space (social processing) in a double-blind intranasal oxytocin study with healthy adult participants; addresses social cognition (affiliation/understanding others). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during theory-of-mind tasks (social cognition) and included a healthy control group (n=14). Participants are adults (siblings and patients), fitting the 17–65 range. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Event-related fMRI study in healthy human subjects examining social communication (gaze and pointing cues). The abstract does not report participant ages; per screening instructions, include for full-text review to confirm age range and other methodological details.

Participants are children aged 3–5 (not within 17–65 adult range) and the study used resting-state fMRI examining DMN development rather than an fMRI social-task or social processing in healthy adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are preadolescents (children/adolescents), whereas inclusion requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65. Although an fMRI social-cognition task was used, the sample age falls outside the eligible range, so the study is excluded.

Original fMRI study with healthy volunteers performing social cognition tasks (theory-of-mind reasoning about cooperation and deception). Directly assesses perception/understanding of others using fMRI in humans; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

fMRI study examining theory of mind and responses to unexpected social vs non-social events—clearly a social-processing task. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; include for full-text review to confirm at least one group of healthy adults (17–65) and other eligibility details.

The study used resting-state functional connectivity and structural analyses in adults with autism spectrum disorder; it does not report task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults, nor clearly include a healthy control group performing a social task. Thus it fails the requirement for task-based social fMRI in healthy participants.

Study reports fMRI during an observe/imitate emotional faces task (social processing) in a sample of healthy adults (n=28, analyses n=20) within the target age range. It is an original empirical study (not a review) and meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract identifies this paper as a review ('we review') rather than an original fMRI study; it does not report a specific fMRI experiment of social processing in healthy adults. Per exclusion criteria (systematic reviews/meta-analyses), exclude.

Not a task-based social fMRI study in healthy adults. The paper reports structural MRI subtyping in individuals with autism and resting-state fMRI findings; participants are clinical (ASD), and no task-based social-processing fMRI in healthy 17–65 sample is described.

Abstract focuses on BPD patients and anger/aggression; it does not state whether a social-related task was used or whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

Sample consists of adolescents (developmental sample assessed annually), clearly outside the eligible adult age range (17–65). Also the fMRI measures report risk processing/cognitive control (not a clearly social-related task).

fMRI study investigating impression updating (perception/understanding of others) during a social task. Abstract indicates human participants and neural measures; no evidence it's a review or clinical-only sample. Abstract lacks explicit age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study with 18 adult participants performing a social cognition task (predicting others’ behavior, theory-of-mind vs deontic inference). Involves perception/understanding of others and impression updating; participants appear healthy and age range fits. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants examining social perception of others’ pupillary responses (social salience/other-understanding). Meets inclusion: social-related task, functional MRI, healthy adult sample. Not a review.

Event-related fMRI study comparing processing of emotion words vs control words; includes typically-developing control group (healthy participants). Task probes emotional/social semantic processing relevant to social cognition. No exclusion criteria met; abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adults examining self-face recognition, which fits 'Perception and Understanding of Self' social processing. Functional MRI was used during a self-face recognition task; no clinical populations or review article indicated. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measuring neural responses to observed actions (mirror system) in human participants; task involves perception/understanding of others (social cognition). Appears to involve healthy adult participants. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

Abstract examines neural correlates of social cooperation/non-cooperation in a dyadic social interaction and likely involves neuroimaging, addressing social processing. However, it does not explicitly state use of functional MRI or participant ages. Insufficient detail to exclude; include for full-text review to confirm fMRI methods and that healthy adult participants (age 17–65) are included.

fMRI study using a social interaction task (virtual handshake; acceptance vs refusal) and includes a healthy control group (n=16) of adults. The study directly examines social processing and is not a review/meta-analysis, meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a narrative review of model-based fMRI approaches to social interaction and mentions BOLD imaging in healthy humans, but it is unclear whether the paper reports original fMRI data in healthy adults versus being a review. Not explicitly a systematic review/meta-analysis. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Participants are autistic children/adolescents and matched typically developing children, not healthy adults aged 17–65. Although an fMRI social task was used, no healthy adult group in the target age range is present.

fMRI study of pain empathy (social cognitive processing: perception/understanding of others) with experimental perspective-taking manipulation. Includes a healthy control group (n=21), presumably adults within the 17–65 range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Empirical fMRI study with 44 healthy participants performing explicit social trait judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) of voices, addressing social evaluation/perception of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits the review objective of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of face perception (social processing) using the Thatcher illusion; includes a matched healthy young adult control group (20 neurotypical adults, likely within 17–65). Task probes perception/understanding of others (eyes/mouth), meeting the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition (direct vs averted gaze) with human participants; includes a matched healthy control group (23 controls) within typical adult sample. Task targets perception/understanding of others, meets inclusion criteria. Not a review.

The study examines reward circuitry (monetary and object-image incentives) in individuals with ASD and controls, not social-related processing. The task is incentive/reward-based rather than measuring social affiliation, communication, or perception of self/others, so it does not address the review objective.

Study used fMRI while participants performed a social provocation (Taylor aggression) task probing social/emotional processing; sample comprised 93 healthy adult males (within target age range); neural responses to social provocation were measured. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social processing (empathy/sympathy) in healthy human participants; sample age range 7–40 includes adults within 17–65 (17–40). No exclusion criteria (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of Theory of Mind/intentional causality (social cognition). Abstract reports group differences with reduced TPJ response in ASD, implying a comparison (likely healthy control) group. Include for full-text review to confirm presence/age range of healthy participants and extract relevant data.
Resting-state fMRI in young children (mean age ~5) with ASD and controls — not a task-based social-processing fMRI study in healthy adults (17–65). Does not meet population or task criteria.

The abstract describes a multi-method review/meta-analytic synthesis (lesion work, TMS, MVPA, and Neurosynth analyses) rather than reporting original fMRI data collected from participants performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Study reports functional MRI during a social attribution task with both healthy control participants and BPD patients. Healthy adults were included and neural activity during social processing was measured. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study investigating social communicative intentions/prosody and neural mechanisms—directly relevant to social communication and perception of others. Abstract describes fMRI task involving categorization of prosodic expressions and social inference. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study using a passive viewing task of disgusted in-group vs out-group faces—directly addresses social perception/understanding of others. Abstract implies healthy adult sample and task-based fMRI; participant ages/health not explicitly reported, so include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study using the Cyberball social exclusion task (social-related processing) and includes a healthy control group alongside clinical groups. Although ages are not specified in the abstract, participants are described as adults (women) and meet the review’s criteria for inclusion for full-text review.

fMRI study with healthy subjects performing familiarity judgments of personally familiar, famous, and unfamiliar faces — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Participant ages not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=30) performing social-emotional tasks (gender identification of angry and happy faces), addressing perception/understanding of others. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults; include for full-text review.

fMRI study of a social attribution task (inferring causes of others’ emotions) and reports a healthy control group (n=16). Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion cannot be confirmed from abstract), so include for full-text review to verify age eligibility and extract details.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (61 white males) performing a social perception task (evaluating faces by race and socioeconomic status). This directly addresses social processing in healthy adults and is not a review.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (mothers without current mental disorders) performing an emotional face recognition task involving perception/understanding of another (own child) — fits social processing in healthy adults. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.
Participants are adolescents (13-year-olds), outside the required healthy adult age range of 17–65; therefore the study does not meet the population inclusion criterion.

fMRI study examining neural integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions—directly relevant to social perception/understanding of others. Abstract indicates whole-brain fMRI analyses and dynamic causal modeling. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study in healthy college-age participants examining emotional memory retrieval for a competitive social sporting event involving fan identity and group perspective. Task taps social cognition/affiliation (social bonds, fan perspective). Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI studies conducted while participants judged persuasive messages (social-cognitive/mentalizing task). Samples are healthy adult groups (American and Korean) and include video/text media; not a review. Fits the review objective of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI was performed while participants viewed emotional faces (a social cognition/perception task). The study includes a healthy control group. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and other details.

fMRI study investigating animacy perception/mentalizing (social cognition) using human participants. Abstract indicates social-related task and neural activation in social brain networks. No evidence of exclusion criteria; participant health/ages not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults aged 17–65.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=42, ages within 17–65) performing a social-related task (understanding self and other's internal states in romantic interactions). Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

fMRI measured brain responses while participants (football supporters) viewed social group–relevant stimuli; study examines social cognition/group bias (social-related processing). Not a review/meta-analysis and appears to involve healthy adult participants, meeting inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing.

fMRI task assessed pain anticipation and fear of movement (observing/rating exercise videos), not a social-related task. Although authors mention neural regions linked to social cognition, the study’s primary construct is pain/fear, so it does not meet the review’s social-processing inclusion criterion.

This study used resting-state fMRI to assess intraparietal sulcus functional connectivity and genetic effects (LIMK1). It did not involve a task-based social-related fMRI paradigm, so it fails the inclusion criterion requiring a social task, despite involving healthy adults and social-processing regions.

fMRI study assessing social reward (agreement with music experts) and non-social reward; includes a matched stimulant‑naive healthy control group, directly examining social processing. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age criteria.

This study is a quantitative meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study with participants; it therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Although it included healthy controls, no social-related task was performed, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criterion of task-based social fMRI.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (rfMRI) to predict gender and does not involve participants performing any social-related task or social processing paradigm. Does not meet the requirement for task-based social fMRI in healthy adults.

Functional MRI study with 27 healthy adult participants performing social interaction tasks probing intention understanding (mentalizing and action understanding). Addresses perception/understanding of others, fits the review objective. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Study reports fMRI of healthy adults performing a Socio-affective Video Task involving witnessing others’ distress (social-related processing: compassion/empathy). Fits population (healthy adults 17–65) and task-based fMRI inclusion criteria; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of action imitation/observation (social cognition via the mirror neuron system), which matches the review’s social-related task requirement. However, the abstract does not explicitly state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included or participant ages. Insufficient info to rule out inclusion, so include for full-text review.

Original fMRI study where participants imagined personally familiar others—a social cognition task involving perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample and other details.

fMRI study investigating processing of dynamic vs. static facial expressions—clearly a social perception/interpretation task. Abstract describes three fMRI experiments but does not specify participant ages/health status. Include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65) and meet inclusion criteria.

This is a resting-state fMRI study in Williams syndrome and matched controls, not a task-based fMRI of social-related processing. Inclusion requires functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults; no social task is reported, so it is ineligible.

Abstract reports fMRI study of theory-of-mind (social processing) in CHR youth and neural networks, but does not specify inclusion of a healthy control group or participant ages. Insufficient information to determine presence of healthy adults 17–65, so include for full-text review.

fMRI during the Embedded Figures Task, which is a perceptual/visual task rather than a social-related task. Although authors relate activation to social-severity measures, the task itself is not social, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criterion.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task assessing social-related processing, and participants are described as adolescents (not clearly within the 17–65 adult range). Thus it does not meet the task-based social processing and adult-age inclusion criteria.

fMRI measured neural responses to facial expressions (social cognition). The study includes healthy participants (independent replication sample of healthy Caucasians) alongside clinical groups, and is not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, but presence of healthy adult participants meets inclusion; include for full-text review.

fMRI study of empathy (social-related task) including a typically developing healthy control group. Abstract reports participant ages 12–31, so it’s unclear whether the healthy group is fully within the 17–65 adult range; insufficient detail to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and extract data.

Abstract addresses social information sharing and neural valuation—relevant to social processing. However, it does not specify that a functional MRI scan was conducted or report participant ages/health status. Insufficient methodological detail to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study using an interactive face-to-face joint attention task (social processing). Includes neurotypical adult participant groups (n=14 matched, n=22), so meets criterion of at least one healthy adult group (adults likely within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI tasks were saccadic and pursuit eye movements assessing sensorimotor control in autism, not social-related processing. Although healthy controls were included, the paradigm does not involve social cognition/interaction; abstract provides no social task information.

The study used resting-state fMRI (dFNC) rather than an fMRI task involving social-related processing. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during a social-related task; although healthy controls are included, the absence of a social task leads to exclusion.

Abstract reports atypical frontal activation during visual attention in autism relatives, suggesting neuroimaging of social/attention processing. However it does not specify fMRI use, participant ages, or that the task is explicitly social. Insufficient details to rule out inclusion — include for full-text review.

fMRI study using emotional face stimuli during a gender-discrimination task (social-related processing: perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy genotype groups (no clinical population reported). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

fMRI study examining action observation and motor pantomime (mirror system) addresses perception and understanding of others—falls under social-related processing. Includes healthy adult participants (sighted volunteers) and uses functional MRI. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants performed a social decision-making task involving another person controlling choices (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Participants are healthy; study is empirical neuroimaging, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are young children with autism (ASD); no group of healthy adults aged 17–65 is included. Study does not examine fMRI social processing in healthy adult participants, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI during affective speech comprehension probes social cognition/Theory-of-Mind processes. Study reports data from 51 participants (presumably healthy adults) performing social-related tasks; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria; full text can confirm ages/health status.

fMRI study investigating perception of social actions in LOTC using RSA, clearly addressing social-related processing in humans. Abstract indicates experimental fMRI work with participants but does not specify ages/health status; include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy adults using a socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation task (psychotherapist instructions). Investigates attachment/affiliation (Adult Attachment Scale) and social cognitive processing with task-based fMRI, meeting inclusion criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of social-related emotion attribution/empathy (SELF vs OTHER) in healthy adults, addressing perception/understanding of self and others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating anticipatory sensorimotor processes during active interpersonal touch (human vs inanimate targets), addressing social processing and perception/understanding of others. fMRI was conducted on human participants (implied healthy adults); not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports investigation of brain activation during emotion processing in unaffected siblings of schizophrenia patients — emotion processing is a social cognition task (Perception/Understanding of Others). Participants are described as unaffected (healthy) adults. Modality not explicitly stated as fMRI, so include for full-text review to confirm scan details.

fMRI study in healthy adult mothers (N=23) viewing own/standard infant videos—task assesses social/attachment processing (affiliation). Meets age and task criteria; not a review. Sufficient detail in abstract to include for full review.

The article is explicitly a systematic review and meta-analyses of fMRI studies (per title/abstract). This meets the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses' so it is not a primary fMRI study for inclusion.

The article is a review summarizing neuroimaging studies in autism rather than an original fMRI study reporting primary data. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not provide evidence of an fMRI social-task in healthy adults.

Functional MRI was used with healthy adult participants performing face perception, similarity-judgement, and face-recognition tasks. These tasks probe perception/understanding of others (social processing), meeting inclusion criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI data were resting-state (rsfMRI) rather than collected while participants performed a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social processing; although healthy adults were included and the topic is social-cognitive, the absence of a social task means it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

Modality mismatch: study used EEG (ERP and time-frequency analyses) rather than functional MRI. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan during a social-related task; although participants were healthy adults and task is social, the absence of fMRI means exclusion.

fMRI study involving healthy participants including an adult group (18+), examines social influence (expert advice) during decision-making and reports activity in social-cognition regions (TPJ) — consistent with social-related processing. Not a review article and meets age and methodology inclusion criteria.

Study uses mouse (rodent) resting-state fMRI; no human participants or social-task paradigm. Focuses on mouse connectome and default mode network, so does not meet inclusion criteria requiring human fMRI during social-related tasks.

Empirical fMRI study with 46 healthy adult volunteers performing theory-of-mind tasks (emotion, belief, pain judgments) addressing perception/understanding of others (social processing). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of joint attention (social communication) using an interactive task in human participants; not a review. Abstract does not explicitly report participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

fMRI study of healthy human listeners performing auditory emotion discrimination (social communication/perception of others), fits social-related processing in adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract indicates neural responses in auditory cortex and amygdala during affective voice processing, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adults (n=98) involving social-processing tasks (judgments about self, friends, and others assessing closeness/similarity). Fits inclusion criteria (social-related task; healthy adult sample within target age range). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Study investigates birdsong and proposes frameworks and animal fMRI; participants are non-human (songbirds). Does not report fMRI in human adults performing social-related tasks. Exclude based on wrong species (animal study).

Study used 3T fMRI during a multiround trust game (a social relationship task) and reports a healthy comparison group of women. This meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing with healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

The study used transcranial magnetic stimulation (disruptive TMS) of the rTPJ, not functional MRI. It therefore does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan during a social-related task.

fMRI study in healthy adult men (n=10 per group) using viewing of romantic (affiliation/attachment-related) and sexual stimuli—task probes social/affiliative processing. No psychiatric/neurological disorders reported and not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of automatic neural responses to masked facial emotions (social/attachment-related processing) in a sample of 51 healthy adults; assesses attachment avoidance (affiliation/attachment construct). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of trustworthiness appraisal (social processing) in Borderline Personality Disorder and reports comparisons to controls, implying a healthy adult control group. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) addressing social-related processing, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social self/other evaluations (social-related processing). Includes a healthy young adult group (ages 22–31), which falls within the 17–65 inclusion range. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full review.

fMRI study of healthy participants watching short film scenes evoking emotional conflicts; task involves social-emotional processing and engages regions implicated in social cognition (STS, IPL). Meets inclusion: functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study with healthy participants investigating recognition of visual feedback/self–other distinction, which maps onto ‘Perception and Understanding of Self/Others’ (a social-related construct). No exclusion criteria met; age not specified but includes healthy adults. Include for full-text review.

Abstract explicitly states this is a review presenting results from ERPs and fMRI studies rather than reporting original fMRI data. Excluded per the criteria that systematic reviews/meta-analyses are not eligible.

Abstract does not specify imaging modality or participant details but addresses parental brain and social bonding (social processing). Insufficient information to confirm fMRI and age range, so include for full-text review to determine whether a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults was conducted.

Functional MRI was used in healthy adult participants performing a social task (receiving negative social feedback/social evaluation). Participants are healthy adults (men) within the target age range. Study is original fMRI research, not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study investigating neural responses to eye gaze (social attention perception) in typically developing (healthy) adults; not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text to confirm age range and detailed methods.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants classified emotions from dynamic avatars—task assesses perception and understanding of others (social processing). Abstract reports neural responses in emotion and biological-motion regions. Not a review or meta-analysis. Sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI results linked to hippocampal activity, used an experimentally induced out-of-body illusion during a social interaction task, and involves healthy participants; this fits fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Study used positron emission tomography (PET), not functional MRI. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Although task involves deception/social interaction in healthy adults, the imaging modality does not meet the criterion.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based fMRI paradigm assessing social-related processing. Although it examines social relationships, there was no social-related task performed during scanning, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring fMRI during a social task.

Task-based fMRI using a social-rejection (Cyberball) paradigm assessing social processing. The sample includes an adult group (16 adult female participants), presumed healthy, meeting the review’s adult age criterion. Therefore the study addresses the meta-analysis objective and inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI neural activity during emotional face processing (a social perception task) with effects in amygdala, fusiform, and insula, meeting the review’s focus on social-related fMRI. The abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages (17–65), so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.
Participants are children in middle childhood (ages 8–12). The meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65, so this study does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

Participants are described as adolescents with autism and their siblings—i.e., a non-adult sample. The meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants age 17–65; abstract indicates adolescent sample, so does not meet age criterion.

Study includes an fMRI facial emotion processing task (social-related) and a healthy control group (n=27). Not a review or meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

Randomized, placebo-controlled double-blind fMRI study using an interactive social task (Prisoner’s Dilemma) in human males and females. Examines neural/behavioral responses to social interaction in healthy adults and is not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI studies.

Study uses fMRI in human participants on social-related task (cross-modal recognition of other people’s identity — perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy sample; given insufficient detail on age/health, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI was conducted during a social-related task (contemplation/imaginary sentence completion about mothers and fathers). The study includes a healthy control group of volunteers (ages not specified but likely adults) alongside patients with schizophrenia, and it is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review.

The study used resting-state fMRI with a pre-scan criticism manipulation rather than an active social-related task performed during scanning. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social task; thus it does not meet the task-based criterion.

This publication is a voxel-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies in schizophrenia. The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses. The abstract does not present primary data with a healthy participant group.

This article is itself a systematic review and meta-analysis of imaging studies (not a primary fMRI study). Exclusion criterion disallows reviews/meta-analyses; abstract does not report original fMRI data on participants. Therefore exclude.

The study examines cognitive emotion regulation to positive/negative pictures but does not investigate social processing (no social stimuli, interactions, or measures of affiliation/communication/understanding of others or self). Therefore it does not meet the review’s social-related task requirement.

The article is explicitly a review and meta-analysis (title and abstract state this). The exclusion criterion disallows systematic reviews/meta-analyses, so it should be excluded. Additionally, it does not report an original fMRI study of healthy adults in the abstract.

fMRI study of implicit facial emotion (fear) processing—a social cognition task—includes a healthy control group (24 adults). Task assesses perception/understanding of others; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while healthy participants performed a social communication task (perceiving messages believed to be from a friend vs a computer). The study examines social processing (social communication, perception of others) and is an original research article, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

This study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Although healthy control participants were included, the inclusion criteria require fMRI during a social-related task, which is not met.

Event-related fMRI measured responses to infant cries/faces (social stimuli involving affiliation/attachment and perception of others) in 17 healthy nulliparous adult women. Meets inclusion criteria (fMRI social task, healthy adult group) and is not a review.

Abstract reports resting-state fMRI and meta-analytic/task-related coactivation parcellation but does not state that participants performed an in-scanner social task. Although social cognition is discussed functionally, the abstract lacks clear evidence of a social task with healthy adults. Insufficient information to determine eligibility — include for full-text review.

This article is a meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation across 28 fMRI studies) rather than an original fMRI study with participant data. The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

The study used magnetoencephalography (MEG) rather than functional MRI. The meta-analysis specifically requires fMRI studies; abstract gives no fMRI data. Although participants are healthy adults, imaging modality exclusion is clear from abstract.

Task-state fMRI examines self-referential processing (a social-related construct: perception/understanding of self). However abstract does not specify that the task explicitly involved social/self-referential stimuli nor the ages of healthy controls (may be older than 65). Insufficient information to rule out inclusion — include for full-text review.

fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition/perception and understanding of others) in human participants; reports task-based activation in canonical ToM regions. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original research article (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract lacks details on whether fMRI was task-based during social processing and whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Title indicates social cognition and DMN connectivity (likely fMRI), but information is insufficient to determine inclusion. Include for full-text review to confirm task vs. resting-state and presence of healthy adult participants.

This study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and focused on individuals with autism spectrum disorder; the abstract does not report data from a healthy adult control group aged 17–65. Therefore it does not meet the task-based social-processing and healthy-participant inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of supraliminal fearful face processing (social/emotional perception) and includes a healthy adult control group (n=25). Task is social-related; participants are adults. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study investigating gesture planning/execution (social communication) with both schizophrenia patients and a healthy control group matched for age and demographics. Task assesses social action/communication relevant to review. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Functional MRI study in healthy adult participants investigating social cognition (self-referential processing and perspective taking). Fits review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Study uses resting-state fMRI and meta-analytic connectivity (MACM) / structural covariance rather than a task-based fMRI of participants performing social-related tasks. No evidence in abstract of an experiment with healthy adults performing social tasks, so it fails the inclusion criterion requiring task-based social processing fMRI.

Abstract reports fMRI connectivity in autism spectrum disorder and links to clinical severity; it does not describe a social-related task nor a healthy adult participant group (17–65). Does not meet review objective of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of perspective-taking during self- and other-referential processing (social cognition). Includes a healthy adult control group (24 typically developed adults). Meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

Abstract reports hyperscanning fMRI of joint attention, a social cognitive task aligning with the review objective. It is not a review/meta-analysis. The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adult participants (17–65).

fMRI study of cognitive empathy (a social-related task) conducted during scanning; includes a healthy control group (n=24) alongside schizophrenia patients. Adult sample implied; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of self-referential (social-related) processing, matching the review topic. The abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Abstract studies amygdala responses to emotional faces (a social-perception task) suggesting functional imaging, but does not explicitly state fMRI or whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient abstract detail to confirm eligibility — include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social processing (integration of facial emotion and eye-gaze) in healthy adults. Includes a healthy younger participant group aged 17–27 (within required 17–65 range), satisfying inclusion criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsFC) rather than a task-based fMRI during social-related processing. Although healthy control participants were included and social measures were assessed behaviorally, no fMRI social task was performed, so it does not meet the criterion of a task-based social-related fMRI study.

Study sample comprises children and adolescents with autism spectrum disorder (and likely age-matched controls), not healthy adults aged 17–65. The review requires at least one group of healthy adult participants (17–65); criterion not met based on abstract.

Abstract reports fMRI functional connectivity related to autistic/social traits in neurotypical adults but does not specify a task-based social paradigm. Because it’s unclear whether scans were task-based vs. resting-state, include for full-text review to determine if a social-related task was performed.

fMRI study of fearful face processing (social/emotional perception) including a matched healthy adult control group (ages consistent with adults). Task probes social brain areas; meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

Abstract addresses oxytocin modulation of socially relevant cue processing in the human VTA, implying social processing. However the abstract does not explicitly state that a functional MRI task was used or provide participant ages/health. Insufficient methodological detail — include for full-text review to confirm fMRI task and healthy adult sample.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of facial emotion processing (a social-related task). It studies individuals at clinical risk for psychosis, but the abstract does not explicitly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Information is insufficient to confirm exclusion, so include for full-text review.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task) and did not report any social-related task or measures of social behavior. Although healthy controls were included, the review requires task-based fMRI of social processing, so this study does not meet inclusion criteria.
Resting-state fMRI in adolescent early-onset schizophrenia; no social-task paradigm and participants are adolescents (not healthy adults aged 17–65). Fails primary inclusion criteria.
fMRI study of facial emotion perception (a social processing task) with both women with MDD and a healthy control group. Healthy adult participants included; meets inclusion criteria.

Study samples pediatric/adolescent participants with social anxiety rather than healthy adults aged 17–65. The abstract indicates clinical adolescent groups (pediatric social anxiety) and does not report a healthy adult sample; thus it does not meet the age/participant criteria for inclusion.

Abstract does not specify methods or participant details, but title/aim indicate neural mechanisms of oxytocin on social stimuli—likely an fMRI study of social processing. Given insufficient methodological detail in the abstract to confirm fMRI and sample, include for full-text review to verify that a functional MRI task was used with healthy adults.

The study investigates phonological short-term memory and visuomotor processing of sign language (letters vs. fingerspelling), not social-related processing. The task is a memory span of nonsense syllables rather than social communication, affiliation, or perception/understanding of others. Therefore it does not meet the review’s requirement for a social-related fMRI task.

Abstract reports fMRI data using the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test (a social Theory of Mind task) in a non-clinical cohort, matching the review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Although structural analyses were performed on stroke patients, the presence of a healthy fMRI group warrants inclusion for full-text review to confirm age range and details.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (fALFF) rather than a task-based fMRI paradigm probing social-related processing. Although it reports prediction of social cognition scores, no social task was performed during scanning, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI social task.

Resting-state and diffusion imaging study of visuospatial working memory in adolescents (including ASD); no social-processing task and participants are adolescents, not healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a resting-state fMRI study in adolescents with autism (clinical sample), not an fMRI task-based study of social processing in healthy adults aged 17–65. Therefore it does not meet the review’s population or task-based inclusion criteria.

Primary data fMRI study examining neural responses to famous people and abstract social words (social concepts), across modalities. Tasks assess social-related processing (knowledge about others/social concepts). Likely conducted in healthy adult participants and not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

The study used an fMRI precision visuomotor (sensorimotor) task in individuals with ASD; it does not assess social-related processing and does not report a healthy adult group aged 17–65. Therefore it fails the inclusion criteria.
fMRI study of theory-of-mind (social cognition) in 109 healthy adult volunteers. Meets inclusion: social-related task, healthy adults within 17–65. Not a review.

Primary data fMRI study of social cognition (visual perspective-taking/understanding others) in humans; not a review. Participants appear to be healthy adults (typical cognitive neuroscience sample). Meets inclusion criteria—include for full-text review to confirm exact ages and participant health status.

Study uses fMRI to investigate emotional processing (relevant to social cognition), but the abstract does not state whether a healthy adult control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine inclusion based on abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. The meta-analysis requires fMRI during performance of a social-related task; therefore this study does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports BOLD functional data focused on the face-processing network in healthy young adults, which is relevant to social processing (facial perception). However, it does not specify whether fMRI was task-based or resting-state; include for full-text review to confirm task-based social paradigm.

fMRI study in 20 adult participants performing observation and imitation of communicative (social) vs non-social gestures, directly addressing social communication processing. No clinical population indicated; meets inclusion criteria for healthy adults performing a social-related task.
Resting-state fMRI in youth aged 8–15 (not adults 17–65) and no social-related task or social processing — does not meet age or task criteria.

Study uses fMRI to investigate social context processing (faces) and includes a group of typically developing (healthy) participants. However, participants are described as 'boys' with no ages reported; inclusion requires healthy participants aged 17–65. Age information is insufficient in the abstract to determine eligibility, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and other details.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in youth with autism rather than a task-based social processing paradigm, and participants are clinical youth (ASD), not healthy adults aged 17–65; does not meet inclusion criteria.

The abstract describes a review of brain-imaging studies (systematic/narrative review) rather than an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

Abstract describes social-emotional approach–avoidance control in healthy participants but does not specify that functional MRI was used. Insufficient information to determine imaging modality—include for full-text review to confirm whether an fMRI social task was performed.

Abstract mentions social interactive deficits in borderline personality disorder but does not specify use of fMRI or inclusion of healthy control participants. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone; include for full-text review to confirm task-based fMRI and presence of healthy adults (17–65).

Study used fMRI during a social cognition task (inferring others' emotions/beliefs) and included a group of typically developing (healthy) participants. The abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so full-text review is needed to confirm age eligibility.
Resting-state fMRI study focused on autism spectrum disorder; no task-based social processing paradigm described. Does not meet criterion requiring an fMRI social-related task in healthy adults.

fulltext_screening_results.reason: Although the study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants and addresses social cognitive processes (ToM, face/voice perception, biological motion, language), the group-level voxelwise analyses reported were restricted to a bilateral STS mask rather than presented as unmasked whole-brain statistical maps. The Methods state that second-level analyses were limited to the STS mask and results/figures focus on STS-restricted activations. Therefore the paper does not provide an unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation map for the healthy adult group, violating the review’s whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.

Although the study includes a healthy adult control group (female HCs, ages 19–36) and uses an fMRI social task, it does not report an unmasked, whole‑brain, group‑level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. Reported whole‑brain results are primarily between‑group contrasts (e.g., BPD>HC for social vs non‑social cues) and an ROI (amygdala) analysis for feedback; no standalone HC whole‑brain task-evoked map or within‑group HC contrast is presented. Because the review requires at least one group‑level, univariate whole‑brain task activation map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group, this paper fails that inclusion criterion and should be excluded.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI (Cyberball) in adults and reports whole-brain group-level activation maps (EX>IN, SUP>EX), the sample includes a mixed group of 37 healthy participants and 9 participants meeting criteria for social anxiety disorder. The paper reports group-level whole-brain results for the entire sample and regression analyses across the whole sample, but does not present univariate whole-brain task effects reported separately for the healthy/control subgroup. Per the review’s eligibility rule that studies including clinical groups must report healthy-group results separately, this study does not satisfy that requirement and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study using a social-interaction task (Cyberball ball-toss) that manipulates frequency of social interaction. Participants were healthy adults (initial N=38, final analyzed N=31; mean age ~21, right-handed, no neurological/medical disorders), within the 17–65 age range. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (ball-toss [high-frequency – normal-frequency] > button-press [high-frequency – normal-frequency]) with voxelwise threshold and cluster-level FWE correction, and provides peak coordinates (e.g., right ventral striatum [22,0,-8], precuneus [6,-44,42]). Analyses are univariate task activations generalizable to healthy adults, not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. No exclusion criteria are met. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the review.

This paper reports task-based fMRI on a social-cognition construct (understanding others’ regret — perception/understanding of others). Participants are healthy adult volunteers (two studies, each N=24; ages in reported ranges ~20–31), meeting the 17–65 age criterion. The analysis is whole-brain, group-level, univariate voxelwise (SPM5 random-effects, parametric and conjunction analyses of IP vs IF and OP vs OF), with reported statistical maps and activation foci/coordinates and cluster reports. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and healthy-group task activation maps are clearly described and generalizable. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using the Taylor Aggression Paradigm, a social interaction task assessing retaliatory aggression (social/emotional processing). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=15 males; mean age 22.3), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate random-effects analyses (GLM) and presents voxelwise statistical maps and Talairach coordinates for multiple task contrasts (decision/outcome phases) and parametric modulation results; results are generalizable to the healthy group (not restricted to an arbitrary subgroup). It is not ROI-only, connectivity-only, nor a between-group-only paper. Although sample size is small and limited to males (noted in limitations), all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be included.

This is a task-based fMRI hyperscanning study in 44 healthy adult participants (mean age 22.4), investigating interpersonal social exchange (cooperation/competition) — clearly within social processing (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate GLM analyses (FEAT/FLAME) with non-parametric permutation correction and provides cluster coordinates and t-maps for multiple contrasts (goal, interaction, role, interactions). Results are voxelwise and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants in age range, empirical original fMRI data). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social communication (speech act comprehension: Naming vs Requesting) in healthy adult participants (n=18 analyzed, ages 18–41). The task directly targets social-related processing (perception/understanding of others and communicative actions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses and task contrasts (e.g., Request > Naming) with FDR correction, and results are described in the text and figures/tables; thus whole-brain univariate task-evoked maps for the healthy sample are available. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, participants are within 17–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study does not meet key inclusion criteria. Sample: participants are adolescents (mean age 14.24 years, range around 14), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Task/domain: the fMRI paradigm is a Monetary Incentive Delay task assessing monetary reward processing (non-social); although maternal affiliation was measured behaviorally, the neuroimaging task does not probe social-related processing (affiliation/attachment, social communication, or perception of others). While group-level task activations are reported, they pertain to an adolescent sample, so do not provide whole-brain evidence generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it fails the age and topical (social-related fMRI in adults) inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (attribution of emotions to human and non-human faces), addressing perception/understanding of others. Sample comprises healthy adults (n=18; ages 21–46) with results reported separately for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., Emotion>Expression conjunction across targets; Face>Scramble) with cluster-level FWE correction and whole-brain maps/coordinates. Analyses are not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or non-empirical methods. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked activation in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social touch (self- vs other-touch), a social-related task (perception/understanding of self and others). It includes a clearly reported healthy adult control group (NC; n=30, mean age ~23.7 within 17–65) with separate results. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps for the control group (other-touch and self-touch vs baseline; FWE-corrected whole-brain results and figures/tables described). Results for controls are reported separately and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes empirical fMRI data in healthy adults). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This fMRI study uses a social judgment task (social acceptance/rejection), i.e. a social-related paradigm. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=20; mean age ~28) reported separately from anorexia patients. The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task activation maps and within-group contrasts for controls (acceptance>control; rejection>control) with cluster-based correction (pFWE) and provides coordinates/figures/tables. Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity analyses. Participants are adults within the 17–65 range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI with healthy adult participants and probes social-affective processing (movie-evoked empathic fear), it does not report group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps for the healthy/control group. The analyses focus on network-level dynamic cohesion (NCI), ROI/network comparisons, connectivity/time-series statistics, and classification; activation results are derived from predefined meta-analytic network nodes rather than whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts. This violates the review’s required ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion and matches the exclusion criterion for studies reporting only connectivity/network/ROI results without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map.

This is an fMRI study of social cooperation (one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma), a social-processing task relevant to perception/understanding of others. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (final n=18; mean age 21.0), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., CC > other outcomes; Gain > Loss; interaction maps) with coordinates and cluster-level FWE correction; whole-brain results are described in text, tables, and figures in addition to ROI analyses. It is empirical, task-based fMRI in healthy adults and does not violate exclusion criteria. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although the study uses task fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=36) and examines vocal emotional (social) processing, it does not report any group-level, voxelwise univariate task-evoked whole-brain activation maps. Analyses are ROI-based (Power-264) functional connectivity and graph-theoretical network metrics rather than whole-brain GLM/activation contrasts. This fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one whole-brain, task-evoked statistical map for the healthy/control group. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=12, ages 20–32) that uses a social-related task (learning facts about people versus buildings and hammers). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise, whole-brain univariate contrasts and conjunction analyses (e.g., person > building and person > hammer), with cluster-corrected statistical maps and region coordinates, generalizable to a healthy adult sample. Although functional connectivity analyses are also reported, these are supplemental and not the sole focus; the primary task-evoked whole-brain results for the healthy group are clearly presented. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult sample, whole-brain group-level univariate maps) and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (imitation/understanding others), conducted in healthy adult participants (n=37; ages 18–25). Reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses (parametric modulation and one-sample t-tests) with cluster-corrected thresholds and peak coordinates/figures, not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only results. Whole-brain PPI is also reported but does not replace the univariate task maps. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=25, mean age 25.1, range within 17–65). The task is social: participants learn about other agents’ preferences relative to the self (social cognition; perception/understanding of others/affiliation). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked results (conjunctions, contrasts, cluster-corrected activations with MNI coordinates) and parametric GLM analyses; whole-brain findings for multiple contrasts are clearly described in text/tables/figures. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not clinical-only). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

While this study uses fMRI during a social-related task (biological motion perception) and includes a healthy adult control group, the reported imaging analyses are primarily ROI-based (STSp and MT) and per-subject localizers. The paper does not provide a clear group-level, whole-brain, univariate task activation map for the healthy/control group (no unmasked, voxelwise healthy-group contrast or whole-brain statistical map is reported in tables/figures for controls). Some whole-brain searches are described (e.g., searching for voxels in patients), but there is no clearly reported whole-brain healthy-group task effect generalizable to the healthy adult population. Because the review requires a group-level whole-brain univariate healthy-control task map, this study does not meet the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (social interaction recognition from point-light displays). The sample includes a healthy adult group (n=16, mean age 28.8, within 17–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (SI > NM) for the adult group with voxelwise results, cluster- and peak-level statistics (including FWE-corrected findings) described in the text/tables. Results for the healthy adult group are reported separately from child/adolescent groups. The study does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses fMRI during a social-related task (HCP Animated Triangles social cognition paradigm; social vs non-social conditions). (2) Includes a healthy adult group (25 healthy controls, ages matched to patients) and reports their results separately. (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts for the healthy/control group (e.g., visual motion and social>non-social contrasts with MNI coordinates, t-values, and FWE-corrected thresholds). Not excluded: results are not ROI-only or connectivity-only (although DCM is used additionally), and healthy-group whole-brain activation maps are clearly reported. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-interaction perception in healthy adults (ages 18–34). It uses task-based fMRI with univariate, group-level whole-brain analyses (e.g., interaction > independent actions contrast; results reported with FDR correction and surface-based random-effects group analysis). Sample size and participant details for healthy adults are clearly reported. The paper provides whole-brain statistical maps/cluster results and meets the meta-analysis’ requirements for task-evoked, whole-brain healthy-group activation. No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (mentalising/theory-of-mind) in healthy adults. Samples include healthy adult participants within the 17–65 range (Experiment 2: N=17, mean age 22; Experiment 1: N=39, mean age 35.5). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise random-effects analyses (second-level ANOVAs) and contrasts (e.g., mentalising > factual; parametric modulation) with whole-brain correction and tabulated/visualized results. The reported effects are univariate task-evoked maps for the healthy group and not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Both participant samples are adolescents (task administered at age ~16), not adults. Inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65). Although the study uses task fMRI of social/introspective processing and reports whole-brain, group-level results, it does not include any healthy adult participants or adult subgroup analyses. Therefore it fails the age/sample inclusion criterion.

This is an empirical task-based fMRI study of social perception (perception of others’ head turns — a ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ social construct) in healthy adults (initial N=21, ages 22–38; final analyses on healthy adult participants). The paper reports group-level univariate whole-brain analyses (nonparametric SnPM and whole gray-matter–masked analyses) with voxelwise results and coordinates (FWE-corrected effects in STS, early visual cortex, MT+, and whole-brain results are described and tabulated/illustrated). Results for the healthy/control group are reported and generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state, includes whole-brain task activation maps). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (social sharing/affiliation) in healthy adults (female participants aged 20–33). The authors performed standard second-level random-effects GLM analyses and report group-level, univariate task contrasts (e.g., shared_emo > unshared_emo) with whole-brain results (whole-brain cluster-level correction reported for exploratory analyses and SPM random-effects model used). Although ROI analyses are presented for VS/OFC, whole-brain task-evoked activations (and cluster-corrected results) are reported and described, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The sample is within the 17–65 age range and results for the healthy group are reported separately. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (guilt vs neutral memories/hypothetical scenarios), addressing social cognition and perception/understanding of others. Participants were healthy adults (mean age 25.7; n=20 proceeded to scanning), within the 17–65 range. The paper reports group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., guilt memories vs neutral memories; guilt memories vs guilt hypotheticals) using whole-brain thresholding (p<0.001, cluster extent) and reports region coordinates and cluster results; thus whole-brain evidence is present and clearly attributable to the healthy group. Analyses also included SVCs but are not limited to ROI-only approaches. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range sample) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical, task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=12, mean age 26) examining perception/understanding of others’ actions/effort (social cognition: perception and understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses (SPM GLM contrasts and polynomial parametric modulation maps) with voxelwise thresholds and SUIT cerebellar analyses; results are described in text, figures, and tables. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, healthy adult group results are reported separately). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI task study of narrative comprehension that explicitly probes social cognition (mentalizing/Theory-of-Mind) during listening to literary stories. Sample: healthy adult participants (N=18, ages 18–27) satisfying the age/sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrasts (Mentalizing > Action and Action > Mentalizing) with corrected statistical thresholds and reports activation clusters (e.g., aMPFC, TPJ, STG, PCC) in text/figures. The study therefore provides healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked maps and is not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or clinical-only results. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

The study uses task-based fMRI of a social-related process (approachability/social judgment). It includes a healthy adult control group reported separately (controls recruited and compared to clinical groups). Whole-brain, univariate task-evoked analyses were conducted (social > gender and condition contrasts) with group- and within-group results and voxelwise inference; within-group analyses and control-group results are described (supplementary tables/figures referenced) and whole-brain cluster- and voxel-level statistics are reported. The paper is empirical, not ROI- or connectivity-only, and reports control-group task activation maps/contrasts generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Study uses task-based fMRI with a social interaction paradigm (ultimatum game) in healthy adult participants (7–10 male subjects aged 23–28). It reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise results from an offline whole-brain classification analysis: discriminating volumes/brain areas (e.g., LPFC, AI, OFC, VS, vmPFC, pSTS, cerebellum) were extracted from transformed SVM weight vectors and statistical significance per voxel was estimated via permutation testing (p<0.05 uncorrected). These results constitute group-level whole-brain voxelwise findings reported in the text/tables and thus meet the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked evidence. The task is clearly social and participants are healthy adults within the eligible age range. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range participants) are violated.

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (empathy toward humans and animals), meeting the review’s construct of Perception/Understanding of Others. Participants are healthy adults (n=60; ages 18–60) within the 17–65 range. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level univariate task contrasts (human negative>neutral; animal negative>neutral) analyzed with SPM; results are reported as voxelwise maps and coordinates with FWE-corrected thresholds and within-group one-sample t tests. It is not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only, and within-group healthy adult task effects are clearly described and generalizable. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction processing in healthy adults (N=21, ages 18–35). The task involves viewing dynamic social interaction videos (arguing, celebrating, laughing). The paper reports group-level GLM analyses for localizer tasks (e.g., interaction>scrambled, bodies>objects, faces>objects, mentalizing>pain) used to define ROIs, and performed whole-brain searchlight analyses—providing voxelwise, group-level task-evoked maps. Participants are within the required age range and results for the healthy group are reported. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not resting-state, not clinical-only). Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy late-adolescent adults (ages 18.1–22.8) performing an action-observation task involving risk-taking vs. safe actions—a social-cognitive paradigm tapping perception/understanding of others and social/emotional processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise SPM analyses (risk-taking vs. safe contrasts) with coordinates, thresholds, and conjunction/mediation analyses; results are presented as whole-brain statistical maps and peak coordinates. Participants fall within the 17–65 adult range and are a healthy control sample. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses, nor is it non-empirical. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although this fMRI study includes healthy adult controls and uses a social cognition task (irony comprehension), the paper does not report a univariate, whole-brain, group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. Results are presented as combined effects across participants and as between-group contrasts (controls > patients) and correlations; the authors note the control-group results were previously published. The exclusion criterion disallows studies that only provide between-group contrasts without an accompanying whole-brain healthy-group task effect. Therefore it fails the ‘whole-brain evidence’ inclusion criterion.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social interaction (joint action: leading, following, mutual) using healthy adult dancers (N=18, mean age 40.4). The study reports group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise analyses and contrasts (FDR-corrected maps, Talairach coordinates, cluster thresholds) for partnered vs. non-partnered conditions, role-specific contrasts, and improvisation effects. It is empirical, not ROI-only or connectivity-only, and results for the healthy adult sample are reported and generalizable. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a naturalistic, socially engaging movie (Toy Story) as a task stimulus and reports group-level, whole-brain nodewise statistical maps for the healthy Adult group (within-group inter-subject correlation maps and peak coordinates). The Adult participants are healthy and reported separately (final N=21 adults), and results are presented as whole-brain statistical maps (with cluster correction and peak MNI coordinates), not ROI-only or resting-state/seed-based connectivity only. The paradigm targets social-cognitive processing and the paper provides univariate, group-level surface/voxelwise tests generalizable to healthy adults. Therefore it meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

The study is an fMRI experiment in healthy adults (N=18; mean age 26) investigating perception and categorization of different laughter types—an explicitly social communication task (affiliation/social signaling, perception of others). It reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain univariate task contrasts (e.g., CSL>TIC, CAT>COU) with voxelwise thresholds, cluster-level FWE correction, and ROI/conjunction analyses. Results are clearly described as coming from the healthy/control group and are generalizable to healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not clinical-only, and participants are within 17–65). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is a task-based fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition: perception/understanding of others) in healthy adults (n=20; age range 24–64). The authors report group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (ToM > R, ToM > Baseline, R > Baseline) with statistical thresholds, cluster correction, and coordinate reporting; figures/tables of activations are described. Results are explicitly from the healthy/control sample and are generalizable to healthy adults. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 17–65 age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although the study used fMRI during a social (patient–physician) interaction with healthy adult participants (N=18, ages 25–37), the neuroimaging results reported are restricted to a priori ROI-based analyses (5 mm spheres) with FWE correction performed within those ROIs.
